author: Patrick F
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2020
review_content: Disappointingly trite.I was looking forward to this book. In fact, it’s the first book in years that I actually pre-ordered. The premise is interesting enough: there is an ethereal library that exists between life and death. You are permitted to choose any book from the shelves and each book contains an alternative life. Each life is what would have resulted if you changed a single decision you regretted. Interesting, right? Like you could see what would have happened if you’d gone for that coffee date or pursued that master’s degree or kept playing piano. In the midst of each new life, if the life-hopper finds herself disappointed, she winds up back at the library to try again. Eventually, you’ll either find a life that is the best possible outcome or your “root life” blinks you away into death.Unfortunately, the premise is played out in the most expected way possible. Nora Seed reverses her regrets and realizes that even the best alternate universes have uncertainties and pain and sadness and disappointment. Even when she winds up with her dream job and a great family, she can’t stay to play this life out. Why? Well, because it isn’t really “hers.” So, surprise, surprise, she ends up waking up from her suicide attempt with a new appreciation for the life she once had and longed to depart.If you read the first 30-40 pages of this book, you’ll probably be able to write the rest of it in your mind. It’s supposedly an opportunity to explore infinite universes, so why choose the most predictable course of actions? To get across the point that you ought to realize the beauty of the life we have around us? Just write a greeting card to convey the message; an entire book is unnecessary. Additionally, it seems like the author either doesn’t understand or chose not to really explore the idea of infinite options. In all her lives, the most remarkably unique one is granted one sentence of exploration, “In one life she only ate toast” (212). Every other life is just variations on themes of work, friends, romantic partners, and family. Of the infinite possibilities available to explore, nothing unexpected happens. It’s maddening as the author keeps smashing his readers over the head with ideas that anything might happen while never delivering on the promise.The writing style is difficult to evaluate. It just feels there. Sentence after sentence slowly moving the predictable story forward. It’s utilitarian prose lacking poetry and depth--seemingly at odds with a book that is attempting to spelunk the internal caverns of a deeply depressed person. The author constantly quotes philosophers but doesn’t seem to have any real interest in engaging seriously with philosophical ideas. It’s a novel in form but a cheesy self-help book in content. This novel is a seed of an interesting idea which was never cared for and died below ground. Unfortunate.D-

author: Schizanthus Nerd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: ‘Would you have done anything different, if you had the chance to undo your regrets?’This was one of my most anticipated reads of the year. It had me at ‘library that contains an infinite number of books’. Then there’s my mild obsession with all things multiverse and my knowing that there isn’t a version of me that doesn’t end up reading this book. I was so hyped up about this book that I preordered three different versions of it. (Sorry, bank account …)What I didn’t expect was to come to the realisation that I didn’t actually like Nora. It took almost no time at all for me to begin resenting her for squandering her potential. She was intelligent and gifted in various disciplines but she bailed on multiple opportunities that most people could only dream of having. Even though I also acknowledged and empathised with the pain she’d experienced, it still took a long time for me to stop being distracted by the privilege she took for granted.‘Never underestimate the big importance of small things.’I loved the idea of being able to test drive different versions of the life that could have been, although it did raise some questions for me. Some were addressed in this book but others are still ticking over in my mind.Nora inhabits the bodies of a number of different versions of herself, all living lives that could potentially have been hers. When she returns to the library the other Noras resume their lives. Nora’s actions in a borrowed life could easily result in consequences that would derail an aspect of the life of the Nora that lives there, and I wondered if I would chance that if I was in her place. I’d hate to think that me acting in an unintentionally careless way could have real world consequences for another version of me.If someone who has their own version of the Midnight Library chooses to stay in one of the lives they visit, what happens to the version of themselves who lived there first? Do they die? Swap existences with the interloper? Or is their existence undone entirely? Also, if you remain in another version of your life, could you ever truly feel like you belong or would you constantly feel like you need to fake knowing people that weren’t a part of your original life?I did eventually get over my initial resentment/envy of Nora’s many opportunities and settled into exploring each new possible life with her. There were some lives I wanted to visit longer and others I wanted to escape from almost immediately. It seemed obvious from early on where Nora’s story was leading.One thing that I hadn’t given much thought to in the context of this story prior to reading it was the impact that Nora’s choices in life, big and small, would have on the other people in her life. In this respect it reminded me of ‘The Butterfly Effect’, although Nora’s story is nowhere near as dark as Evan’s. Paulo Coelho’s ‘Veronika Decides to Die’ and Robert Frost’s ‘The Road Not Taken’ also popped into my mind as I was reading.I wound up thinking a lot about who my Mrs Elm would be and the form that my Midnight Library would take. While my Library would have books (obviously!), I’m still not entirely sure who my Mrs Elm is.I don’t know if it’s possible to read this book without thinking about your own regrets. Equally, I don’t know if it’s possible to read this book without considering the changes you could make in your life to erase them.The story is told quite simply. It seemed to me to be part cautionary tale, part self help book and part Philosophy 101.‘Now go on, live, while you still have the chance.’Content warnings are included on my blog.

author: Mercedes J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_content: I was reeeeeeeally looking forward to this book. Every time I needed a new book to read I came first to this one, constantly forgetting that it wasn't coming out till the end of the month. As soon as it came out, I bought it.Whelp, it was a bit of a disappointment. I did enjoy it, and I loved the idea of it, but it was kind of a letdown in some aspects. I won't synopsize this book as it's already been done here numerous times, but here are some of my thoughts on this story...~ I didn't really like Nora. I have a very...we'll say...'full' personality and I have trouble dealing with/relating to people who are 'poor me' all the time. The only person who can make positive changes in our own lives is US. WE are the masters of our own destinies, so Nora's depression over the life she was leading based on all the choices SHE made was difficult for me to handle. She had some amazing opportunities that people would kill for, and she blew Every. Single. One. Of. Them.Now, I understand anxiety. I have family members who suffer from awful anxiety and without the proper medication, I myself would be on the nightly news every time I have to get on an aeroplane (I hate them they're the devils' transport), but I deal with it. You see a doctor, you find what works for you and you try your best to go about your life. (I understand not everyone can do that, but that's how *I* deal with it). I just couldn't relate at all to Nora's depression and her inability to try and do better for herself when she clearly had so much to offer.~ I REALLY didn't like the fact that every time Nora entered a new life, she was a complete stranger to it. Why? What was the point of making it that way? It was incredibly jarring and uncomfortable to sit through Nora trying to figure out where she was, who everyone was, and what she did for a living and knowing NOTHING about her life. Why make her go through all that each time?How could she get possibly get comfortable in any particular life when within the first 15 minutes she could SERIOUSLY screw it all up by saying or doing the wrong thing? I didn't like it and it kind of gave me anxiety every time I had to read about her floundering and flustering her way through a new life (I know, I know...hush).~ The ending could be seen from space. This wasn't necessarily a bad thing, but just know that there are no surprises here. What you think is going to happen is exactly what's going t happen. While I knew it was coming, I was still happy with the end result.~ I LOVED the Midnight Library. I thought that entire segment of the book was brilliant and I loved the time we spent in there.Overall, I did enjoy this book, but I didn't love it. I think my expectations were a bit too high and it didn't help that I didn't get on that well with Nora. That said though, I would still recommend it. If you're interested in Matt Haig, I REALLY recommend 'How to Stop Time'! I absolutely loved that book. It's still one of my favorites.

author: Dollycat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: Just started reading this book which I got as a Christmas present.  I was really looking forward to reading it after seeing such great reviews for this book both on Amazon and on Goodreads. (Still can't understand why it got such high ratings!!)  After reading the first few pages I immediately began to get a sinking feeling that this book was not going to be what I was expecting and the more I read it,  I see my prediction is going to be right.  There really isn't much substance to this novel to warrant all the positive reviews it has gotten.  While the premiss of the story is a great concept and idea, the way the author delivers the storyline doesn't give it much substance or poignant messages for the reader to dwell on. I was hoping to get something out of it but it basically is just a very flat story with no creativity involved.  For instance, the character of Nora gets the opportunity to experience different lives that she regrets to have never followed through on in her root life. But what is so strange is that while she physically looks and feels different, mentally she is totally not there!!  She has no idea who the people are in these lives nor does she have any concept of what her role is.  For me, I'm finding it so annoying having to read how lost and confused Nora is every time she enters these new lives. Reading about how she has to ad lib her way through them all without any clue about her surroundings or any idea of how she got to be who she is is getting to be so tedious.  It just makes me wonder how is that suppose to give her the opportunity to really feel every nuance of these regretted lives and know if it is better or worse??  In other words, she can't be the person she is in these different lives without some changes to her personality or mental well being if she has changed physically.  Who's to say the character of Nora would be OK with the compromises and choices she made in some of these lives??  Especially in the lives where she manages to become so successful!!  I guess my biggest regret is that I had hopes that this book would have been similar to Mitch Albom's book The Five People You Meet in Heaven.  But it most definitely is NOT.  It think it would have been better if Nora would have gotten to watch herself in those lives rather than live in them muddling her way through just being lost and confused.  So while I pretty much can predict the outcome of this book and already know where it is heading, I will just continue to "muddle" my way through it to read the disappointing ending before I chuck it to good will.

review_content: Scarecrow: What have you learned, Dorothy?Dorothy: Well, I—I think that it, that it wasn't enough just to want to see Uncle Henry and Auntie Em — and it's that — if I ever go looking for my heart's desire again, I won't look any further than my own backyard. Or worse, insinuate that people should just look for the silver lining in life because there are no lives that are untouched by negative emotions, there are just lives. That doesn’t seem very helpful to people in very dark places. I expected more from a Goodreads #1 readers choice. 2.5 stars for prose.

author: Timothy Haugh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: I very much like Mr. Haig’s last novel, How to Stop Time, so it was pretty certain that I was going to read this, which looked to have many of the same qualities of the last one.  Unfortunately, I was very disappointed in this.The idea of “the midnight library”, a place of infinite shelves where all the variations of your lives play out (and an ever-changing book of regrets to guide things) is a great one.  When Nora, our disappointed lead character, enters her library and we get a taste of its powers, we look to be on an exciting trip; however, the episodes that follow quickly become statements of the obvious.  Nora is on a guided quest to learn a sequence of lessons that offer no real interest or surprises.  By the time the end rolls around, any mystery has long since burned away and left an ending we have seen coming for a long while.Perhaps a was a bit jaded when reading this because it seemed to echo the last novel I read (The Space Between Worlds by Micaiah Johnson) which, though it has problems of its own, I like much better.  I also had very high expectations of Mr. Haig, which were unrealized.  This is not a book I would come back to or recommend.

author: nicalibre
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2020
review_content: With the pandemic, the political climate,  the division in the US this year especially,  the state of the climate, the US out of the Paris accords and the embarrassment of a President who acts like a toddler, and all of the suffering by so many around the world due to COVID-19 and job loss and food insecurity; my normal tendencies toward depression  and anxiety have been heightened. And I'm lucky- despite enormous  debt, I have a government job in public health that has continued to pay me and provide benefits, especially health care.But reading the national and international news daily, it has been hard to evade despair.I stumbled upon The Midnight Library, by Matt Haig, quite accidentally, and I am so very glad that I did. About halfway through I found it on a list of suggested books in The Washington Post suggested to read for perspective at this difficult time in the world, and in the US with an especially acrimonious election upon us.I want to thank Matt Haig for this book, which lifted me up, shook me around, and put me back down on my feet with a much better perspective... Haig has helped to remind me of all of the things that I have to be grateful for, and I know that I will read other of his books.The Midnight Library is thoughtful, encouraging,  and meaningful... please take the time to read it. I usually wait to read books on Kindle until they are offered by Amazon at $1.99 or $2.99, but am so glad that I jumped in and bought this at full price.  Do yourself a favor and read this book today!Matt Haig, you have a new follower.  Thank you!

author: Cathryn Conroy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: Two succinct ways I viewed this novel by Matt Haig:1. UnderwhelmedI say that because before I even purchased the book, I knew it had been honored with a slew of "best book" picks from Goodreads to "Good Morning America." Based solely on this, I had certain expectations. They were dashed.2. Boring, banal, and predictableThe saccharine-sweet story set my teeth on edge.Nora Seed is 35 years old and desperately unhappy. Living in Bedford, a small town in England about 50 miles from London, she feels like a failure both personally and professionally. She left her fiancé just two days before their wedding, she gave up on competitive swimming when she had Olympic potential, she did finish university with a degree in philosophy, but never managed to translate that into a job she loved—or even just didn't hate. Her brother isn't speaking to her because she quit their rock band. And her beloved cat has died. So Nora decides to die by suicide. When she is in that state between life and death (presumably in a coma), she arrives at the Midnight Library where Mrs. Elm, Nora's school librarian from way back when, is the mistress of this mysterious place. Mrs. Elm informs Nora that she may choose from all these millions of books on the shelves of the Midnight Library to see how her life would have turned out had she made different choices. That is, what if she had gotten married? What if she had pursued swimming and competed in the Olympics? What if she had realized her career dream of becoming a glaciologist? Or that even crazier dream of becoming a rock star? The bulk of the book is Nora coming back to Earth in the guise of these different lives that would have been.I forced myself to finish it just in case it improved. It didn't. It was mildly amusing at best, boring and banal at worst. Don't waste your money or time on this.
title: Boring, Banal, and Predictable: Don't Waste Your Money or Time on This Book

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: The Midnight Library can be quite a read for a 70+ year-old librarian with a Book of Regrets as packed full of choices and missed or ignored opportunities as both Mrs. Elm and Nora Seed combined. I was drawn to the concept of a library of ME, of endless shelves of lives I could have lived had my decisions been made more mindfully. The trouble is, it's not that simple...As Nora, guided by her personal librarian, proceeds through the proffered lives she experiences, she keeps making the same mistakes of judgment and choice that brought her to teetering on the knife-edge of death by suicide. Every time she returns for a new book of life in the library, after every sound suggestion from Mrs. Elm, Nora proceeds to another life as a path not taken and still finds herself unsatisfied.II appreciated how skillfully Matt Haig wove together Nora's lives, dreams, aspirations,  and perceived mistakes and played them off the variety of people who repeatedly appeared in these lives. And how after all Nora needed only one simple truth to save herself.Work your way through the library with Nora to discover some of your own truth. My husband and I play a variant of the library, an exercise of untangling decisions in reverse to discover how we got ourselves to a place in time or a circumstance. An example is the many events, accidental meetings, while and suggestions that led a non=academic young man from Cleveland and a horse-loving nerdy girl from Montana to end up together in a Lutheran teachers college. Even then,with such divergent backgrounds, how we were brought to meet, become friends and manage untangle other relationships, marry and to live together for 50 years seems miraculous.We all have our libraries. But if we manage to discover our true selves, we can stick with the book we checked out in the beginning.I highly recommend The Midnight Library. It can be read as a good story. It can be a cautionary tale. It can be a plan for self-examination. I enjoyed the developing relationship between Mrs. Elm and Nora Seed, how the older woman guided and taught, encouraging that seed in Nora to grow into the strong tree Mrs. Elm had become despite the regrets that even she still battled.INora's quotes of her favorite philosopher are now entered into my phone. Her  adventures and misadventures are mentally noted because I also learned from Mrs. Elm that age and limited wisdom doesn't give me a pass. I'm not there yet. Peace with myself is as distant for me as it was for Nora as she found herself in the library. Thanks to Matt Haig, I am not as clueless as she was. I don't have to live any superfluous lives, but only my own to figure out my next moves. No meticulous untangling of events to lead me to good choices. It's so much simpler. Life is not that complicated. Expectations make it complicated.It's really very simple to be happy if you aren't looking for pitfalls to spoil it.KL
title: The end can be the beginning

author: KasaC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review_content: I picked this up thanks to a reviewer who called the style and approach to a difficult subject, "comforting."  And after last week's upheavals in the real world, I felt a dose of fantasy was in order.  Enough has been written about the plot line (a library situated somewhere between life and death, where Nora, the main character, can revisit old regrets and dispel them by experiences an alternative reality).  Initially, I found the premise sweet, but became impatient with some of the stylistic choices.  For instance, when Nora enters the life that would have been if a certain choice had been different, she retains the sentience of her "core life," with none of the alternative.  This became tedious very soon.  What I did appreciate was Matt Haig's calling attention to mental health issues.
title: Good idea but problems in execution

author: Elizabeth Clark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: I am writing a review in the hopes that Amazon will never again recommend a book like this, at least not to me. Ironically, for a book obsessed with regrets, the best way to avoid regret is to skip this book. It is predictable and relies on hackneyed, ham-fisted writing. It never takes the time to develop its characters so it has to tell the reader everything, including why we should care. It’s moralizing and lecturing and stilted. To the extent anything about the book is subtle, it is the troubling and unnecessary implications that women should sacrifice themselves to save men or that a single unsuccessful suicide attempt will cure depression. But I may be giving the book too much credit. The overarching premise is to live the life you have, or something.I’m not going into the plot or characters in detail because the author didn’t bother so why should I?  What is infuriating about this book, at base, is that there is probably a good book somewhere in it but it is buried under heaps of contrivances and tropes.  It reads as though the author was so concerned with writing a “feel good” but “deep” novel that he abandoned storytelling.

author: E. Lewicki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: *Trigger warning: attempted suicide and talk of overdose*The Midnight LibraryNora Seed has a lot on her plate. She has just been told her cat had passed away, the only thing she had that she loved, then she is let go from the job she's had for years, and then she loses her piano student. Both her parents are gone, her brother hasn't spoken to her in years, and her best friend is in another continent and hasn't spoken to her in quite some time. She questions her own existence. Why be in a life where you have nothing left to live for? With that, she decides to take her own life. She consumes some pills, and the next thing she knows, it is midnight, and she is in a library surrounded by books, and greated by her old librarian from school. This isn't just any old library, it's her library. There is a huge book filled with her regrets, and each book surrounding her is a path that she could have chosen differently than the one she chose in her root life. So here it is. She has been given the chance to choose a different path in life, any one at all, and can try as many as she likes. Here's the catch, she can continue trying new lives so long as she is still alive in her root life, and she can remain in the new life so long as she is truly happy. Nora sets out to find the absolute perfect, happy and successful life. Is it really that simple? Will she find what she's really looking for before she runs out of time?I cannot say enough about this book! I saw several people post about it and bought it a while back, but then it sat on my shelf. Recently, I've had a lot going on and found myself being swallowed up by a black hole, and something just drew me to this book. It really was the book I needed and had such a huge impact on my outlook in life! What an absolutely amazing book! I highly recommend this book! I rate this book ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ for not only being a truly spectacular book, but for helping me out of my black hole of depression.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
review_content: 2.5 stars, rounded to 3.0 because of the ambition.I really wanted to love this book. The premise sounded amazing, and as someone who suffers from anxiety and depression, this seemed right up my alley.But unlike another recent read with a similar theme (LaRue), The Midnight Library lacked depth. Weight. Substance. I think part of the issue had to do with the book’s structure. The chapters were so short as to be jarring. Even within the confines of a single “life,” we’d come to an abrupt semicolon in Nora’s story every 3-4 pages that ruined the narrative flow and emotional investment. I’m sure this was intentional; there’s no other reason to structure a novel like this. But it didn’t work for me.The other issue I had with this book was lack of continuity. I don’t mean continuity in terms of themes or events—all of that was fine. What I mean is that TML lacked a certain grounding force that kept us invested in all of Nora’s many lives. In LaRue, that grounding force was Luc, and, later, Henry. Addie’s relationships with those characters kept us emotionally invested in her story. Here, Nora lacks depth as a character (again, this is intentional—she is on a journey to find herself after all), and there’s nothing to ground her or the reader. Even Mrs. Elm is just a manifestation of Nora’s own subconscious, and, as such, lacks the required depth to sustain the novel.There were some things I enjoyed about the book, but overall, it just didn’t do it for me. Maybe it’s time to stop reading books about characters with myriad lives...

author: LA in Dallas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: ** spoiler alert **As the book starts, Nora Seed is having a bad day. Like, a really, really bad day. So bad that at the end of it she decides she doesn't want to live and deliberately overdoses. (On antidepressants. Can you actually kill yourself with antidepressants? I thought they weren't very toxic. Well, I guess you can kill yourself with too much of anything...)Normally, of course, that would be the end. But then we wouldn't have a story, so something has to happen. Nora finds herself outside a building, with her watch and the building clock stopped at midnight. She enters and finds herself inside a library. Every book in this library is a life she could have lived. (There is some pseudoscientific mumbo-jumbo about the Many Worlds Interpretation of quantum mechanics to justify this scientifically. It's nonsense, of course. Insufficiently-known fact: Quantum mechanics is actually not the same as magic.) The librarian from her old school is in there. She explains that Nora can pick a life and live it. If she is satisfied, she can stay in that life. But if she is dissatisfied she will find herself back in the Midnight Library, where she can try another book. But there is some kind of ill-defined limit, after which Nora will die if she doesn't get a life.So Nora experiences a bunch of lives, where she learns lessons. We hear about the first several lives in some detail. This is the most disappointing part. It is where Matt Haig presents his not very profound insights into life. It is obvious from Nora's meditations that Haig fancies himself a philosopher. But his philosophy is trite. If you want insight from Thoreau's philosophy, I advise you to read Thoreau, not Haig.This kind of thing has been done before. For instance, I remember a story by Theodore Sturgeon (wish I could remember the name of the story), where a man is allowed to see how his life would have played out if he had made different choices. And there are many others. Reliving ones life with different choices is rather a common trope in science fiction.There's something about the way it works works in The Midnight Library that doesn't make sense. When Nora goes into a new life, she just appears in the mind and body of the her that would have existed had she made different choices. But she doesn't really. The Nora that is put into this situation is the Nora that attempted suicide. For instance, she shows up as the lead singer of a world-famous rock band. In this world she (the she of the new world, whom old Nora has just possessed) has written multiple hit songs. However, new Nora doesn't know any of those songs. She knows nothing of her past in this life except what she can suss out from looking at her social media accounts on her phone. She doesn't know the words of the songs she, the she of the life she has joined, composed. In another life she is a glaciologist, but she, new Nora, has no education in glaciology.Eventually we learn that this was all a con. She finds a life in which she is happy and decides to stay. but she can't:Everything was right, and yet she hadn’t earned this. She had joined the movie halfway. She had taken the book from the library, but truthfully, she didn’t own it.So she finds herself back in the Midnight Library, where everything is falling apart. Literally the only choice left to her is to find the book that represents her original life, the life she came from, and start writing in it. So she finds herself back in her old life, but now with a will to live. She drags herself out of bed, gets taken to the hospital and rescued, and seems as the book ends on the road to a better life.So the whole book is a con job designed to sell a bargain-basement generic life affirmation which you can find much more quickly in a million places on the Internet.

author: commandofthelanguage
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
review_content: “It is easy to mourn the lives we aren’t living. Easy to wish we’d developed other talents, said yes to different offers. Easy to wish we’d worked harder, loved better, handled our finances more astutely, been more popular, stayed in the band, gone to Australia, said yes to the coffee or done more bloody yoga.”The Midnight Library is the account of Nora Seed and her near-death experience thanks to an intentional overdose of medication. On a perfectly ordinary day in her unremarkable, mundane life, Nora finds herself depressed and helplessly watching her life and her relationships unravel before her eyes. Her mother constantly treats her like a mistake, her father is dead, she is estranged from her brother and her best friend, lost her job, and to top it all off, her cat is fatally hit by a car. Fully feeling the weight of her shame and regret, Nora see’s no other way around the consequences of her poor choices and mismanaged opportunities. So, she downs a bottle of prescription anti-depressants and waits for the end of her suffering to come.She awakens somewhere between life and death, in the Midnight Library. After encountering a friendly face from her past, Nora quickly learns that this is not a dream and she is not in just any library. This library contains an infinite number of books, each one telling the story of an infinite number of parallel lives. Her lives. Lives she could have lived if she had made one, or two, or two thousand different choices. Nora is given the chance to step into any of these lives she chooses, to see what they may have been like, and if she finds one that truly brings her happiness, she will be allowed to stay. Before long, Nora realizes that there is no such thing as a life without certain disappointments and tragedy. There is no such thing as perfect happiness all the time, but that doesn’t make her life a failure.The Midnight Library illustrates a scenario most have fantasized about—getting the chance to rewrite our lives by erasing our regrets. The exploration of parallel lives is thoroughly interesting to consider, and readers will widely appreciate the insightful, illuminating message around satisfaction and life experience. Others, however, may argue that the premise alone carries this plot. The dialogue and characters, at times, feel shallow and distant, emotionless and even immature. While the themes themselves (mental health and valuing life) are thoughtful and important, the delivery may fall a little flat for some looking to feel a deeper connection.

author: imaloserdude
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
review_content: So many options can be pursued when evaluating a book.  Did the author create believable and consistent characters?  Did the author manufacture vivid scenes and detailed locations?  Did the author include Easter eggs for the reader to find, anagrams of names (like in the Series of Unfortunate Events) or a play on words or an alliteration or metaphors or similes or puns?  Did the author include references to real world events or people or places that the reader can connect to?  Did the author explore a familiar concept in a new way?  Did the author give the characters words to say that connect with the reader and their view of life?  Did the author overuse actual dialogue or internal monologue to explain the story instead of relying upon actual action.There are so many options for the reviewer, just as there are so many options for the main character in this book.  Nora Seed finds herself in a library at the stroke of midnight, with lots of books around her and a librarian from her childhood, Mrs. Elm.  Each book represents a different version of Nora’s life, a life of joys and sorrows, people and places, events and tragedies that spawned from a single choice, a decision, or in the case of this girl so full of regrets, something that didn’t happen because she didn’t make that choice.Of course, there is the root life, the life that Nora remembers living, a life full of disappointments and settling, that led to her attempted suicide and her visits to the Midnight Library.  A moment in between, where she isn’t alive and in her body yet she isn’t dead (with the finality that means for self and others).  And there are all of those other lives that she now gets to explore, lives where she doesn’t remember any of that Nora’s life, but finds herself plopped there with a kid yet no memory of this child, or as a wife with no memory of sleeping with her husband, or as a glaciologist with no memory of what such a scientist knows, or as a pop star with no memory of the words to popular songs, or as a pub owner with no memory of what to do when closing.  Lives, but without the memories that led her there.An interesting thread running throughout the book is that of Hugo, another slider who explores his own lives.  Hugo and Nora meet up several times, though find that the other isn’t what they want and each chooses to go back to their own terminal, hers a library and his a video store.  I expected them to meet up at the end, as they had such a powerful connection through their sliding, both aware of themselves and of others, but no.  it wasn’t to be.  I’m not disappointed, just wondering if such a possibility exists, and if I will get this chance one day.  And I wonder how Hugo arrived at this point, if his was also a suicide, and if it only happened to suicides or lives so filled with regrets.A question I still have is about the character of Mrs. Elm (for Nora) or the uncle (for Hugo) and the place where these shamans or guides or facilitators resided.  Both sliders found themselves in an in-between place with a familiar character as the trusted one, not someone who used them but someone who in real life helped them find their own way.  A good person.  An older person who helped at a pivotal time in their life.  I find it cool that the author (Matt Haig) crafted a god-like character, not one who superimposes her/his will on you but one who is limited in what they can do by the physics of the world (a library or a video store) they are trapped in.  Not all-powerful.  Not desiring worship.  Not governed by human impulses (power and sex).  But a personal god whose sole interest was in the needs and wants of a single person, a much better concept (to me) than the invented gods of the modern world that seem interested in humanity as a whole (and worship and knee-bending and blind obedience and all of that stupidity).  If we could wipe away all of the old gods and create a new god for each person today, this would be the kind of god I would like to think about.  Though there is that question about universality, and whether everything we think and feel isn’t just arising from our own experiences, including all of this god-talk.I enjoyed finding things in this book.  Like the title, on page 31.  And the name of the band, a variation of the Kurt Vonnegut classic, Slaughterhouse Five.  And the name of the music shop that sounds like the idea behind all of the lived lives in this book, String Theory.  And the references to Bedford and Pottersville, connecting readers to the classic movie, “It’s a Wonderful Life”.  And life-fright being similar to stage-fright.  And the role of chess in the book, from its beginning to its end, something that used to be a major part of my own life as an educator.  And glitches in the library that stemmed from Nora thinking differently about death than she did in her root life.  And I had to look up “grasshopper suicide”, because the character told me to, and how many forms of life there are (almost nine million), and Frank Ocean (“Moon River” was awesome).Another interesting concept is that of time.  Time doesn’t pass for Nora in the real world as she pulls out numerous books from the library shelves, some exploring for a few minutes, others for hours or days or months.  Yet the clock never moves past 12:00 in slide after slide, life after life, universe after universe, until her thinking changes in such a way that she no longer regrets the choices she made in her root life.  And then the clock starts ticking and Mrs. Elm warns her that she must do just one thing in order to survive, pick that one book, and, wait, I don’t want to spoil it for you, but it gets to 00:03:48.If you want to know what happens to Nora, then read this book.  It is really good and worth your time.  And if you are the philosophical type (as I am), then keep a notepad and pen nearby so that you can write down the interesting thoughts and ideas that flow from the mind of Nora Seed, the questions she ponders, the truths she shares with the world.  And I will end on a final thought, one found on page 137, about life and what it is:  “…acres of disappointment and monotony and hurts and rivalries but with flashes of wonder and beauty.”  Something to think about.
title: Full of philosophical aphorisms & lots of Easter eggs & ideas about happiness and choices and life

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: Between life and death there is a library and that is just where Nora Seed finds herself after swallowing a whole bottle of pills.  Within that library the shelves go on for ever with every book providing a chance to try another life you could have lived; to see how things would be different if you had made other choices.  Would you have done anything different, if you had the chance to undo your regrets?’Bertrand Russell wrote that ‘To fear love is to fear life, and those who fear life are already three-parts dead’.  Nora had once backed out of a Wedding, her excuse based on her mother's recent demise.  Even knowing that a person is like a city, with a few less desirable parts- dodgy side streets and suburbs, but that the good stuff makes it worthwhile, Nora still opted for the single life.‘Want,’ the Librarian tells Nora, in a measured tone, ‘is an interesting word. It means lack. Sometimes if we fill that lack with something else the original want disappears entirely. Maybe you have a lack problem rather than a want problem. Maybe there is a life that you really want to live.’ ‘Referring to a life she has just tried and returned from, Nora responds : I thought that was it. The one with Dan. But it wasn’t.’After another life cycle, Mrs. Elm, the Librarian, tells Nora that sometimes regrets aren’t based on fact at all but just lies.  When Nora questions Mrs. Elm why she just didn't tell her that the outcome would be the same in this new life as it had been in her root life; Mrs. Elm responds:  "Because, Nora, sometimes the only way to learn is to live.’"When Nora  discovers a life she thinks she wants, she remembers the words of Mrs Elm on her first visit there: "If you really want to live a life hard enough, you don’t have to worry . . . The moment you decide you want that life, really want it, then everything that exists in your head now, including this Midnight Library, will eventually be a dream. A memory so vague and intangible it will hardly be there at all."Every life contains many millions of decisions. Some big, some small. But every time one decision is taken over another, the outcomes differ. An irreversible variation occurs, which in turn leads to further variations.Life begins on the other side of despair. - Jean-Paul Sartre
title: A Life Recycled

author: J. Medina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2020
review_content: “It is a library of possibility, and death is the opposite of possibility, understand?” This was such a special book if I do say so myself. author: M. Bennett

author: Constant Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review_content: This is an extremely popular book, but it is also a disappointing book. The premise is intriguing, but the execution is lacking. Matt Haig could ask more of his readers and give us a more thoughtful book. We never get much beyond the premise: the midnight library is a personal purgatory/bardo/limbo space between life and death. The space is tailored to the person. For Nora, it is a library staffed by her beloved school librarian. For someone else, it might be a totally different space. In the Midnight Library, Nora is invited to examine her book of regrets and to select from an infinite number of books that contain her alternative lives that result from different choices. Nora ends up in the Midnight Library after a suicide attempt. She does not know yet if the suicide attempt will be successful. The beginning of the book shows us Nora’s unhappy life and then the rest is Nora popping in and out of different possibilities. Nora as the married owner of a country pub, Nora as the international pop star, Nora as the happily married mom, Nora with the live brother, Nora with the dead brother, etc. If you remember the old Quantum Leap television show, entering each life is a bit like that except it is always Nora jumping into another Nora. But like the television show, the root Nora does not know anything about the other Nora’s life. The story is predictable as it leads Nora to realize that many of her regrets were not her fault. Perhaps Nora’s experiences would help a reader realize that he or she is just not that important. For example, Nora’s failure to smile at a customer did not cause her beloved record store to go out of business. This book plays to the modern focus on the individual’s happiness and egotistical self-importance instead of a larger view of a life of purpose, work, love, and service which ironically can lead to more personal happiness or at least contentment. Never fear, there is a happy ending. This book is very readable, and the pages turn fairly quickly. The tension level remains low even when the library is crumbling or when Nora hits a snag in a life. Bottom line: better than some, worse than some. Warning: there are moments of preachiness and attempted suicide is a major feature. I did like this book more than How to Stop Time and if it helps anyone decide not to commit suicide then it is brilliant.
title: Good Premise, Light on Depth, Not Great, but Not Bad

author: Rennie Walker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2020
review_content: Sometimes we have to genuinely forgive some, or a lot, of a 5-star book to let it be and shine as a 5-star book.  The Midnight Library is one of those books.  It is as exceptional as all the editorial reviews, taken together, score it.  But, know that it has its dullnesses.First the beautiful, moving and inspiring.  Nora, spiraling downwards, drowning in regrets and lack of any and all hopes, is struggling (to state it mildly).  She finds herself in the Midnight Library, attended by Mrs. Elm, the librarian.  In fact, Nora really, really, NEEDS to be in the Midnight Library.  There she reads her Book of Regrets.  It is thick and heavy.  Each book in the library is a life that is different from Nora's root life, but is a life that could have been Nora's root life if she had made a different choice, large or small.  Obviously, then, the number of books in Nora's Midnight Library is infiniteThe purpose of the library is for Nora to find a book (an alternative life) that she loves/prefers and for her to stay with that life and live it. Each time she enters another life and then leaves it to return to the library, the regret in question that she had of herself burns away, and her Book of Regrets becomes lighter.  Nora tries out some other potential lives that she could have lived - mega-famous rock star, glaciologist, married and co-owning a country pub and so on - but each one is not a good fit for her.  And so she returns to the Midnight Library.Mrs. Elm the librarian, is also a life counsellor/coach/mentor.  She teaches Nora how to search for what she is really after.  And so Nora learns, snippet of alternative life after snippet of alternative life, what she is seeking for.And so to what we have to forgive of The Midnight Library.  Some of it is charming and some stretches of it come across as cutesy; so that depends on your tolerance for cute and cutesy.  The Midnight Library itself is "explained" in the context of the highly abstract and speculative theoretical physics notion of multiverses and parallel universes.  We really don't need to know THAT for the library to exist; so it depends on your tolerance for a modicum of highly abstract physics concept.  This reader didn't care and didn't pay any attention to this.  And as for the guidance that Mrs. Elm offers to Nora, some of it comes across and wise and some twee.  So again, it depends on your tolerance.This reader came to fall in love with The Midnight Library.  But know that at 20% (reading on Kindle) I was unsure; and then at 20% an event happened that took me in wholeheartedly.  In conclusion, with forgiveness, the editorial reviews are a fair reflection of the beauty and wonder to be found within this story.  Yes, it is, or just might be, inspiring.
title: Beautiful, Moving, Inspiring, but Slow and Dull in Places

author: LeeLee8081
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: Have you ever wondered how your life would have turned out if you had changed just one thing in your past? How would something that you did or did not do impact another person’s decisions for better or worse? What if you could change actions that you regret? What if you could rewrite your past? With a different past, what would your present look like? This book’s protagonist, Nora Seed, is given multiple opportunities to explore the answers to these existential questions. Having arrived at “The Midnight Library” on the brink of death by suicide, she is mystified to encounter her school days librarian, Mrs. Elm, presiding over the scene. She guides Nora to examine the regrets of her past that have led her to want to die, and then she gives Nora a choice to open any of the books on the shelves. Each book that she chooses draws her into a life that she might have had if she had not experienced a regretful event in her past. Through book after book Nora experiences her life as it would have been if she had changed something that she regretted in her past. She drops into each life and stays just long enough to learn that she needs to move on and try another life. In her search for the perfect life, Nora learns more about herself and her family every time she lives in her alternate life. At long last, she realizes that there is no perfect life. There is only the life that she has and it is enough.Due to its focus on exploring some pretty deep psychological issues, I found the story less engaging than I had hoped. I also had a hard time relating to the mechanism of dropping Nora into her alternative lives as a stranger unfamiliar with the people, places, and situations she arrived in. Everyone knew who she was and what she was doing there, but she constantly had to play catch up as she scrambled to fit in as if she belonged there. All in all, it was not one of my favorites but it gave me food for thought and I was satisfied with the ending.
title: What life would you live if you could correct past regrets?

author: Ann Marie Norrid
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2021
review_content: This was the perfect book club pick to end 2020 on.Our protagonist, Nora is depressed and just about as many bad things that can happen to a person all happened to her at once. Nora attempts suicide (Heads up: suicide is discussed throughout the book) and is immediately transported to a sort of “in between” realm in an endless library. Each book in this infinity library is a different version of her life. So while she’s in this limbo, she can try on her other lives to rid her life of regrets. Yeah, just go with it.This is a simple, straightforward fantasy-ish book. It doesn’t depart from the plan and didn’t cause any anxiety on my part, which is nice sometimes. Not every book has to have me on the edge of my seat with tons of twists and turns. Plus there’s some great philosophy in it, but nothing too heady.What I loved the most about in this book is the way it celebrates an ordinary life. It’s the small lovely things in a life that add up to make it a great one, not necessarily becoming an Olympic swimmer or rockstar.While there was a time or two where I thought, ehhh, I think the book is being a smidge flippant about depression, I thought it was a great book overall. Plus, the chapters go by very quickly so it’s a fast read.The last couple of pages got a bit sappy, but that’s okay. It’s been a hard year and we DESERVE a sappy, sweet, precious ending, right?? 🙌🏼🙌🏼🙌🏼Go read this book. After 2020, we need it.

author: Lauren Peterson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: Here I go again with an unpopular opinion, but I was one of few who found "The Midnight Library” to be a middle of the road read. I was honestly shocked when I saw it was Goodreads book of the year. I read "Dark Matter" earlier this year and that may be the problem. Like "Dark Matter," this book touches on inter dimensional travel, changing lives and consequences of doing so. The problem is "Dark Matter" is the far superior read in my opinion and I kept comparing the two since they had so many similarities. The story is about a woman named Nora who commits suicide only to find herself in a midnight library with a chance to try on numerous different versions of her life (each in the form of a new book) until she gets it right—or until she dies. The premise is fascinating and I wanted to be all in, but I wasn’t. I thought it lacked depth and for such an emotional journey I felt incredibly unattached to our main character.
title: Unpopular Opinion

author: CVP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: Amusing and clever, this is really one of a million memoirs/self-help books crowding the shelves now.  Most novelists - and almost all in the past times -  used characters and story to tell their  beliefs.  But this book is less "novelistic" than a Dickens or other writer's.  Fair enough.  And it would have made as good a table game as it is a book. And while I've only read a few articles on parallel universes, the technicalities in this book don't make sense. Granted, it's not a thesis on the subject, but the notion of someone going in and out their various lives is as silly as it is fascinating. Life doesn't open up like portrayed here. Every step you take actually limits the next steps you can take. Also, a physicist will tell you that life's like a Rubik's cube. One change changes everything else. So the novel - and its main character - is absurdly solipsistic and rather cruel. I kept wondering what happened AFTER she left one of her lives. The scenes of the people she left behind and what they did would be more interesting than her whining. Or the story of what the Nora whom she replaced did when the narrator Nora left would have been more interesting.  But it wouldn't have made everyone happy. Anyway, maybe there's a shelf between fiction and memoir/self help that someone can put this book on. Or wait for the movie.
title: A self-help book disguised as a novel

author: witchieone1031

review_content: I'm not much of a writer but I was compelled to write about this book.  This book made me think. I thought about this book more importantly I thought about my own life. title: Life in review

author: Misty M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: I loved this book SO much! It was everything and more, wrapped up in a teeny tiny package!  This was a quick read & listen for me because, of course, I had to do both!The exploration Haig takes readers on is unlike any I've read before; all of those comparing this book to a modern-day “It’s A Wonderful Life” retelling with a sci-fi twist would be right on point. The very idea of being at the end of your life, by choice (TW: suicide), and then given a chance to revisit a life’s worth of regrets and play out an endless amount of possible what-if scenarios (think along the lines of the multiverse) was absolutely mind-blowing. The way Haig tackles the tough topics within, barely scratching the surface, is like a breath of fresh air. To think about any choice, big or small, you have made or could ever make, and its impact on your life, in the long run, brings about a deep and impactful internal discussion. Or at least it did, with me.I enjoyed Nora Seed’s journey and immensely adored the ending and the message between the lines.Nothing I say could genuinely bring this book justice. You need to read it for yourself.I'd recommend this book to literally everyone. This is easily a top read of 2021 for me!
title: I loved this book SO much!

author: Julie Saffrin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Just finished this remarkable book. Rendered speechless. What a writer Matt Haig is. And wow, what a tour de force of a story. Beautiful words crafted into thought-provoking sentences. The Midnight Library is a moving, well-executed modern-day tale that champions humanity. One will truly be a different person after visiting The Midnight Library and Nora's encounters at 00:00. Matt Haig, without specifically saying so, has the main character explore Thoreau's famous line about humans "lead[ing] lives of quiet desperation." And he has done so in clever, very moving way. As well, Carey Mulligan shines as a fantastic narrator, bringing each character to life, using her own special talent by way of innuendoes, perfect pauses, lilts, even mundaneness - never once over-acting - something most American actors have need of to learn. Both Haig and Mulligan takes each person created in this story and brings them to characterized perfection. This book has been optioned as a movie. Can't wait to see how this story is brought to life in film. My only wish in this story was that Haig would have had the main character explore Christianity alongside legendary philosophers' points of view. Nonetheless, this is a book well worth reading.
title: A story that shows life's fragilities, hardships . . . and beauty

author: John B. Sinclair
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
review_content: Who doesn’t wonder what would have happened in their lives if they had made a different decision on which path to take at the proverbial Robert Frost fork in the road? I met my wife in a bicycle class 25 some years ago. What if I didn’t make the decision to call her after the several-days class was over? That and so many other decisions over the years, sometimes seeming minor at the time, have had such long-lasting consequences.The Midnight Library is quite the fascinating opportunity for one character, Nora, to explore possible alternatives to her life when she believes her initial life has been a failure. She is given the opportunity to decide whether she would prefer to continue living in any of these alternative realities. It is intriguing to observe how those different paths do not lead to the future(s) Nora was expecting. Most interesting for me was realizing how what may seem wonderful to the alternative life seeker may have negative consequences for those whom one loves.Overall, the author does an excellent job, at least initially, in pacing the narrative and moving it along smartly. A few complaints that move this book down  to 4 stars. The ending is fairly predictable. The book does bog down a bit 2/3-3/4 into the narrative but then gathers speed for the journey to the end. When Nora spends time with her child in one life, the author describes Nora’s previous experience with her children in other lives as lasting “only a couple of minutes or so.” This statement conflicts with a previous chapter and life (as a vineyard owner) where the details of her life, involving a son, clearly could not have been ascertained in just a “couple of minutes.” Persnickety of me? Perhaps.The Midnight Library is a book that is easy to recommend. Fun to read and thought-provoking. What else can a novel reader ask for?
title: A Woman Who Gets to Explore the "What Ifs" of Her Life

author: Helen M. Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021
review_content: Unlikable and self-absorbed protagonist does nothing to get you rooting for her.  So, she could have been this, that, and the other.  Who cares? Boring, and verging on the edge of being a preachy 'be grateful for what you've got' sermon. This book has been so over-hyped.
title: Blah!  Over-hyped book of the year.

author: Lfreese3
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
review_content: I wanted to like this book but I ultimately found it to be painfully predicatable.  There were no surprises in this book.  I knew which lives Nora would vist and what she would learn. I knew exactly where how the book would end almost from page one.  To me it felt like the author needed a device that would move Nora from point A to point B as easily as possible.  The result was that there was no depth.  The perception is that we carry around a book of regrets and the heavier that book is the more unhappy our life is.  All we have to do to be happy is get rid of our regrets one by one.  We are only in each long enough for Nora to undo the regret associated with it or learn the lesson she needs to learn to move a step closer to point B.  It just felt like Nora went from Suicide to wanting to live way to easily.  Nora was never forced to really deal with the insecurities and fears that caused her to choose not to live any life over and over again.  There were excuses like, the cat would have died anyway or those lives were someone else's dreams, but there was no reckoning with why she was unable to take any action to live any life.  Because of all of this the end of the book felt hollow and unearned.
title: Very Predicatable

author: BrownPaperBunny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
review_content: I loved this book. Loved it. In fact, I can’t stop thinking about it. Nora Seed hates her life, and tries to end it, only to find herself in a strange library with an infinite amount of ever-moving books. Her school librarian is there, and tells her that there is a book for every version of her life that could ever exist, based on each decision she’s ever made.And the best bit? She can open the books and step into those lives, to see what they would have been like, until she finds the life she wants the most. But with every life there are challenges to be considered and overcome.It’s a moving story about finding your path, your happiness, and being your truest self. It’s all a matter of perspective really.I loved Nora, and found myself hoping (so hard) that she would find her happy-ever-after, her dream life, the one where all the stars aligned just so. It was a beautifully written book and one I’m sure I’ll be thinking about for a long time to come.Potential trigger warnings for cheating, self-harm, drug overdose, parental death, and suicide.

review_content: just because you use words like quantum physics it does not make it science. philosophers have been postulating the nature of existence and our choices for a long time.as does the lead character Nora. mostly dissatisfied with life Nora overdoes and takes a trip to the Midnight Library. title: more philosophical  than science fiction

author: CynB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library, by Matt Haig, is an unusual, compelling novel that explores the impact of choices on the trajectory of a life.  How would any choice (or non-choice) affect the outcomes of the life lived? Are your regrets real?  In other words, were the consequences the result of your actions or did they have no impact whatsoever?This is not a book about libraries nor is it science fiction.  Perhaps, it can best be described as fantasy mixed with philosophy.  I found it riveting, but I’m fairly certain it won’t appeal to everyone.  The protagonist is profoundly depressed, truly believes that the world would be better off without her. She attempts suicide, and in a strange space between life and death, she is given an opportunity to experience lives she might have had given different choices. Some alternate lives were more interesting than others.  Each provided insight as to how limited our perception is.  I found inspiration and affirmation in this story.  I am happy to suggest you give it a try!
title: Life Affirming Fantasy

author: Love to read
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: While there may be other books that cause you to reflect on the paths not taken in your life, the approach to this story was original and creative. I won't give away spoilers, but the gist of the novel is that a woman is given the opportunity to experience how her life could have been if she had made different life choices. As is the case with all of us, her decisions led her on a particular path. The main character in the novel has the opportunity to find out how other potential lives would have turned out because those lives are documented in books, all of which are in the Midnight Library.  As I read the consequences of each life that she didn't really live, I couldn't help but reflect on my own decisions and how my life may have turned out, had I made different choices. This is a fast read, but one that gives you lots of food for thought. Do you regret how some of your life has turned out? Are you grateful? Perhaps a little of both? The author's unique approach to this common theme is refreshing an intriguing.
title: An unusual and engaging read

author: Hannah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2021
review_content: I found this book to be very interesting. It just makes you wonder about your own life and where your decisions have taken you. I don’t think by any means that this is so boring that you stop reading it, I was intrigued the whole time, sometimes people can be so harsh on reviews. I would recommend reading it, especially if you’re in a book club, I can’t wait to discuss this one with the girls. I think the only thing I disliked about the book was there was to much philosophical verbiage in it. ...one last thing I just have to say is that I’m really annoyed with the one star reviews that say it’s basically being insensitive to those who have tried to commit suicide. THE BOOK IS FICTIONAL!! Im pretty sure if someone with suicidal tendencies had a chance to explore every option in life then they more than likely would come out with a more positive view on life, but because life can be depressing due to the lack of having other options, then yes it can stay sad, but unlike Nora, she got to live and see the beauty in life versus always living in a life of depression. ...you can’t fault the author for creating an unrealistic world. If you want real, stick with biographies and non-fiction and stop hating on people for their imagination.
title: I liked it! ...1 star people need to stop hating.

author: Big D Reads
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: He wrote another book called How To Stop Time. That book was good. This one is GREAT. It's very Groundhog Day. It's very Back To The Future, with a bit of Defending Your Life or It's A Wonderful Life. If you like those pieces of art, read this one!And if you love this book, you should read What Death Taught Terrence. Both this book and that one are similar. Terrence is cool because the main character is someone we rarely read in fiction.Happy reading!
title: I Love This Author!

author: SunRise
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: When I purchased this book I expected it to be an interesting read.  The topic was interesting and it certainly has good reviews. Unfortunately I have found it to be a total bore.  Very uninspired writing.  I still have a couple of chapters to go but may not bother.
title: A Very Disappointing Read

author: Claudette
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: Seeing the reviews that this book is trite, predictable, simply written I understand where they are coming from. About 40 pages in you can basically fill in the entirety of the plot. That being said I have decided that the plot is not the point of this book. .This book is essentially the Alchemist by Paul Coehlo but modern and, in my opinion, better. It’s written similarly, although the fable-like structure sits a bit strangely in the present day setting of the book. Each sentence is written to lead you to the main character’s revelation, much like the lines of the Alchemist. The characters other than Nora are, for the most part, flat and included solely to contribute to Nora’s pursuit of her “personal legend” (to put it in Alchemist terms). The overall points of the two books are also quite parallel, looking at the meaning of life and love. However, the Midnight library in my opinion approaches these questions in a less narcissistic manner (not just leaving a girl waiting for you in the desert because for some reason her “personal legend” is entirely dependent on yours).Overall I think the lessons the book intended to teach weren’t new. I’ve read plenty of other novels that tackle the same questions— however, I do think this book contains a few lines that added to the discussion and for that reason it is, in my mind, worthwhile.
title: The Alchemist Reincarnate

author: Lori L. Fox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library by Matt Haig wasn’t what I expected, but it turned out to be more than I expected. I wasn’t prepared to cry at the end, nor to relate to the experience of letting go of regrets and understanding the concept of parallel universes that exist inside of us. This book is an affirmation of life and endless possibilities, of the power and importance of choices.The most powerful line in the book for me is on page 286: “She could plant a forest inside herself.” Just typing it gives me chills.Recent studies confirm that reading novels teaches us empathy and compassion. Too often we think of those terms in relation to others, but this book shows how these terms relate not only to others but also to ourselves.The Midnight Library is a book I will definitely return to and think upon often. I wasn’t prepared for its totally satisfying ending, but it’s perfect.
title: “She could plant a forest inside herself.”

author: Jan Day
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021
review_content: I bought this book for my book club but only read 137 pages. It is so depressing and right now that is not the kind of book I need to read. Another friend said she kept reading it hoping it would get better but she said it never did...
title: Depressing Book

author: J. Money
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2021
review_content: I enjoyed this book. Is it predictable? Yes. Predicatability isn't always bad. Not everything was predictable, however. There were moments of surprise which led me to wonder what would come next. From other reviews many seem disappointed and their expectations weren't met.Not everyone is going to like this story (which is apparent in the review section), but I personally appreciated the theme of perspective, possibility, and dreams. Along with these themes I find that the story is a commentary on the idea of being a 'self-made' person and living out the dreams of others. How both of these avenues can ultimately lead to unfulfillment. It displays how important relationships are in life and how there is a delicate balance between the need for others and the need to dream. The story felt hopeful and I think sometimes in life a simple message like that can speak volumes.
title: Perspective, Possibility, & Dreams

author: Megan Urbanik
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review_content: Okay... I bawled incessantly throughout the book. From the first sentence, I was hooked! The way the author describes regrets and helps the reader see different aspects of living a life that is full. Different choices bring different realities into being! Do I personally believe in the idea of a multiverse in which every choice I make could have led to something different? Not really. But do I believe that life is worth living no matter what choices we’ve made? Yes! I’ve felt like the main character at times in this story. I’ve had dreams, regrets, idea I wanted for my future that didn’t come true. This book helped me see different things I may have been missing. My only complaint is the ending left me a little hollow. I wanted to see more of the story than we were given. But that is the only thing I could imagine wanting.The book is a *clean* book with swearing.
title: Heart wrenching and soul moving!

author: Barbara Peschl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
review_content: Seldom does a book come along it’s so accurately describes all of our fears at the moment we are our lowest in life. It describes in achingly accurate prose the despair every one of us has felt when life occurrences lead us down a path of regret.But the joy of discovery and the most important message from this work of literary brilliance is that the one thing we all must remember is that it’s all temporary. The key to JOY is understanding that it’s temporary, the key to despair is to remember that it’s temporary, the key to success is to remember that it’s temporary, the key to failure is to remember that it’s temporary.It is the temporary nature of highs and lows that gives life depth, because we never know the outcomes of all the choices we make for ourselves and others.Since it’s a New York Times bestseller, you don’t need me to tell you to read this book, but if you don’t it will be a choice you make that you will miss out on something really amazing.
title: A life review, of every life.

author: Seattle Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2021
review_content: I just finished this book and could hardly wait until it ended.  I finished it because...well, hope springs eternal.  I should have looked at the reviews before buying it.  I did NOT like Nora the protagonist who wished and wished for a perfect life but was never satisfied with anything.  The author seemed to grab on to a theme of "what would have happened if we had made different decisions along the way?"  But it was not at all successful.  I did not find a single character to like or even slightly care about.  IN fact, many other reviews said it better than I am but I felt I just had to add my voice and my extreme disappointment on a book which has been appearing on the best seller list every Sunday.  Not at all deserved!  IN fact the only reason for the 2 rather than 1 star is because I was able to read it to the end of its short but seemingly interminable 299 pages.
title: THIS was on the best  seller list?

author: Amelia Grace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021
review_content: This is best book I have ever read. And I have read a few (over 500 non-fiction books in the last five years to be precise). It turns out that I read so many books because I was desperately hunting for...this.I didn't consider myself depressed or suicidal. 'Realistically and rationally miserable' seemed to be an apt description of my life. I lugged around the most enormous book of regrets imaginable, lamenting choices, missed opportunities and squandered potential. Despite constant efforts, it seemed impossible to turn the doomed ship of my existence around. I viewed my 42-year-old self with contempt, embarrassment, shame, and sometimes outright despair. Despite my quite reasonable achievements, I could only see was what I was not.As I read this book, and followed Nora through various alternate lives, my own regrets took on a less glamorous sheen. It seemed obvious, upon closer examination, that these alternate lives (hers and mine) were almost certainly naive and unrealistically formed fantasies. You can't pick and choose the best bits. You get one life, and all the wonder and pain it entails.I don't believe in parallel universes (I believe in determinism). But this book showed me that my current life is not just the ONLY one that could have been, but that perhaps it is the BEST one. At any rate, it occured to me with earth-shattering clarity, that I would choose it again if all the options were on the table. After all, I DID choose it - step-by-step - the end result of a sequence of choices across the years, each time choosing what I thought was best.Those who complain that the ending of this book is predictable have missed the point. Of course the ending is predictable. We all know what the ending SHOULD be. The problem is that no one knows how to get there, and this book shows you how.In essence, I remembered that I AM ALIVE. And I WANT TO LIVE.
title: Don't listen to the negative reviews

author: RJG McManus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library by Matt Haig is about a woman named Nora Seed who, in a moment of extreme desperation and dissatisfaction with her life, decides to commit suicide. Immediately upon overdosing, she finds herself in the Midnight Library, a limbo if sorts, where there are infinite shelves filled with books about the way her life could have gone had she made different decisions. She's given the opportunity to "try on" lives, so to speak, and the chance to choose a different life for her consciousness to slip into and keep living. The only catch: if she finds herself dissatisfied with any of the lives she tries, she will be sent back to the Midnight Library, unable to enter that life again...and time is against her, as her body is dying in her root life. If it dies before she finds a new life, she will also die.The best way I can describe this book is it's something of an updated "It's a Wonderful Life," where we see how each small decision Nora made impacted not just her, but her friends and family. I found it to be an easy read, full of imagination and hope. It was utterly charming, with a satisfying ending. It made me think a bit about my own life and regrets, and how even in the things I may be unsatisfied about, life could be much worse. It honestly made me grateful. It really is a wonderful life. 😉As mentioned above, the subject of suicide is broached, so if this is something that triggers you, this may not be the best story for you to read. Otherwise, I highly recommend this book. It's well written with lovely character development and an intriguing plot that has a heartfelt (and at times heartbreaking) message. I give it a 5 out of 5 stars.
title: A modern "It's a Wonderful Life"

author: Travis Noland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2021
review_content: A rather unimaginative use of the quantum wave function as a plot device to drive home a singular message: Don't regret the decisions that led you to this point in life; it could've turned out much worse!The irony is not lost upon me, as the implication that this reviewer's decision to read this book has left me better off.  I doth protest!  At least it was a quick read...
title: At least it was a quick read....

author: Rachel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2021
review_content: This book is definitely the bright spot that I was looking for. And (spoilers maybe) it's true:the problem is regret. It's the regret itself. What's done is done and if it were done any other way who knows what wouldn't be right.Instead of focusing on regret or want or lack, focus on possibility. Today, so says this book, I cam do anything. Today is a blank page that I cam turn into anything I want.... Which I mean may be sleep right now but still. The point is there.
title: Was looking for a bit of hope

author: Mary Ann Foley-Mayer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: Matt Haig wrote a thoughtful and inspiring novel about what it means to be alive and to live life to the fullest. The story is about Nora who has depression and has lost the will to live.  Some people think people with depression are overly emotional and self pitying but the truth is some people with the medical diagnosis of depression fully believe that their life is useless, everything they try to do fails and the world truly would be better off with out them.
