Telling them that this is not true falls on deaf ears because the illness of depression lies to them telling them they are worthless. The author does an excellent job describing the person with depression in a matter of fact tone that is truly believable. I did not feel pity for Nora but instead felt empathy as if I could know what she was feeling.  It is not a depressing book, instead it is uplifting for anyone, depressed or not . We get into patterns that become boring but difficult to break.  Reading this novel helped me see that and make new choices. This is a remarkable book for anyone. I find myself thinking about it after I've read it, a sign of a great book.  I will look for more books from this author.
title: What a wonderful book!

author: Crystal Marshall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
review_content: Honestly I was really bothered by this approach to reaching the Midnight Library. I’ve read two of Haig’s novels and have no been impressed. It’s cliche at best and harmful at worst by glorifying suicide. I won’t be picking up another one of his.
title: Not a fan

author: Arizona Cat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2021
review_content: Absolutely life changing book. After reading this book, for the first time I’m able to see my regrets in a new way. I’ve given this book to three people and they have all had the same transformative experience. Do the work, though. Think about your own situation as you go through each chapter. This book could easily have an accompanying workbook which would guide readers who may not know how to make the connections to their own lives and regrets.Another strange thing was that I had the peculiar feeling while reading it that the author knew me and had peppered it with things that would relate to me. Then my friends who read it said the same thing about themselves. I know the author doesn’t know us, but it felt as though he did. Just a magical transformative experience.
title: Life changing, replaces ten years of therapy.

author: tink
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review_content: I loved this!  Sometimes we get so bogged down in what's going bad around us we forget about the positive.  It was good to remember that every move we make in life no matter how small is significant in the grand scheme of things and that the possibilities are infinite.  Its not the grand dreams we accomplish although good it's the tiny steps that get us there .Our decisions in life affect everything and everyone around us!  This book makes you want to get out there and live!
title: A great invigorating look at life death disappointments and what we don't realise we already have!

author: Chrystal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2020
review_content: In our adult lives, the question “what if” is one that continually plagues us. I have had dreams of different paths that I have taken (different careers, different lifestyles, etc.). This story puts those thoughts into a well-developed sequence of events where a struggling mc explores those options presented in the form of a library of “what ifs”.Although I found the story to be a little predictable in nature, it was still a wholesome idea that encouraged me to stop and consider the facets of my current life that I enjoy. Even in the difficult times, the journey of life has a greater purpose. I appreciate Matt Haig’s awakening of the ability within myself to reconcile with my “what ifs” in my life.
title: What if you could change the course of your life?

author: InfirmBookworm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
review_content: The best, most meaningful book I’ve read in a long while! I’d recommend this to anyone who feels—or has ever felt—out of sync, deeply unhappy, in the throes of an existential crisis, even just vaguely depressed...Haig seems to just get it. He has an outlook on life and a way of putting a thought or an idea into the most beautiful of words... I’ve never highlighted so many gorgeous passages in a book before—ones I know I’ll be coming back to time and time again when I need some inspiration or motivation. The nuggets of philosophy he has sprinkled throughout this gem of a story also make it that much more brilliant. It’s a beautiful life guide disguised as literary fiction. I know I’ll be re-reading this one many times over.
title: Wow!

author: optimusm07
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: This was different than most mental health books I've read. It may be a good beginners guide to addressing negative feelings one may be feeling about life... It's not in your face telling you what you should do or how you should handle things. It allows you to go through different possibilities based on the small decisions we make or don't make. *SPOILER* I didn't like how in each new life, Nora has no clue where she is OR who she is. She has to figure this out each and every time. This does get a bit repetitive and frustrating. I can see how this book would help someone appreciate what they have before choosing to end it. Life tends to feel heavy some times and books help strengthen our perspective.
title: Need to Read Between the Lines

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: Nora is depressed and feels that she has nothing left to live for. Then, she finds herself in a library made up of books containing all her possible lives in parallel universes, with her old school librarian Mrs. Elm as her guide. As she tries out alternate lives, she discovers more about who she is or could be. Some of the other lives seem like they would be perfect for her, but she learns that her regrets may not hold the perfect life she thinks she needs.Nora studied philosophy at University, and we are treated to her insights as she navigates into and out of her multiple lives. The adventures are entertaining even as we root for her to find her way to a life in which she will thrive.
title: Have you ever wanted to change your life choices?

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2021
review_content: Perhaps it  shouldn't be titled The Midnight Library but instead "A life with and without regrets".  This was a terrific book, thoughtful, and takes you on a journey of the "what if?" dimension.  I typically prefer novels with loads of conversations and not long descriptions.  But this book made me re-think that preference.  The author writes beautiful prose, rich, and thought provoking.  It truly was difficult to put down and the ending merely raised the possibility of 'potential' and that was more than enough for me.
title: A wonderful, amazing read !

author: Annie Marie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: An unusual journey from depression to choosing to live, this fantastical (maybe?) book dares to explore the what-ifs in life. I consider it a modern day version of It's A Wonderful Life, in its way. I am glad I read it.Nora Seed, with nothing to live for anymore, plans the day and time of the end of her life, only to have it shelved in the "Midnight Library". She then must examine several volumes of possible alternative lives based on making slightly or greatly different choices from her past.What I love is that no life is perfect, yet her journey is about finding a way toward accepting what isn't perfect, and alleviating regrets by making amends.Merry Christmas.
title: When Regrets rule one's life: a lesson in reframing life.

author: Carla
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: This book was such a journey! I think we all have that dream, what if I would've chosen differently in life? So, this beautiful tale, takes you through one woman's journey... from the despair of thinking you no longer matter in life, all the way up the mountain to what your life could've felt like if you would've chased and conquered your wildest dream. Oddly, I felt a distinct connection to every character in thus book , but you know what? I think that's the magic of this book, teaching us that nothing in our life happens by accident, and every person, every adventure, every encounter is meant to be savored. I highly recommend this book... I got so lost in it, it started feeling like I was a Part of the storyline! Choose this book, and see life in a different light!
title: The Haunting Thought of What Could Have Been

author: Chynna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
review_content: I found this book on a virtual library app with 176 people waiting to read it. After reading the description and the sample, I knew I had to buy it. It was slightly out of my book budget but I took the plunge anyway. I tried to take it slow but finished in about a week. This book was amazing and made me feel so much more sure about my own life. Regret is something that we deal with everyday. We beat ourselves up about decisions we never made and think how different our life would have been. But even despite this, the life we have chosen is the one we have chosen for ourselves. Some things may not have been the good choice at the moment;  but we have each and every day after to make up for it. To change our lives and live for ourselves. This book has had a significant impact on my life. It was definitely a worthwhile read. Thank you Mr. Haig for choosing to write.
title: One of the best books I’ve read in a long time.

author: ShAnNoN
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: I’m glad this was my first book of 2021. Life is more about your perspective and attitude than the actual events. I have so much power, so much to give, so many adventures, so much to tell my loved ones about how much I love them, so many options. Life can be led with limitless options. The only limit is my doubt in myself. It’s up to me to make my life great. That’s what this book reiterated to me. I can lead any life I choose.
title: Great for a New Year ahead

author: Kathryn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: I mostly listened to the audio version of this book. I truly enjoyed it. It was a unique spin on a lot of theories about multiple dimensions where we all live different lives, on the butterfly effect, and theories I’ve probably never heard of. I like libraries. I like books. So, a story that combines those to give a character multiple chances at different lives was right up my alley. No spoilers here. I can just say I recommend this book.
title: Great Read!

author: Barbara Williford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
review_content: “She realised that you could be as honest as possible in life, but people only see the truth if it is close enough to their reality. As Thoreau wrote, ‘It’s not what you look at that matters, it’s what you see.’”Nora is stuck.  She is stuck in depression, stuck in a dead end job, stuck being broke, broken relationships.  The death of her cat sends her over the edge hovering between life and death having to make some tough choices.  It takes facing her regrets, opening her eyes to see that everything we perceive is from our own personal perspective and may not be reality.Excellent writing and deep insight.  A book you won’t want to put down.
title: A must read

author: endlessreader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review_content: This book is one that everyone should read, it's that good.  Perhaps for manyeven life changing.  What would you do if you could choose your own outcome?Being a voracious reader of over 75 books since the beginning of 2021, I've made more personal comments, more highlights,  and so many things to revisit, I cannot say enough how this book will impact your life. The  very way you think about things will change.Since accommodating my reading habit, Kindle is the medium of choice. However, when a book has the ability to change the way you think and act and perceive, I purchase a hard copy too! That says it all. Many thanks to Matt Haig.
title: Excellent content, life changing

author: Kathleen Murphy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
review_content: Enjoyed reading about parallel universes and the twist the author gave to creating the reason Nora experienced the chance to see the different universes had she made different choices. I was disappointed in the author not diving into what happens to the displaced Nora during and IF she chose a different life to take. I was also disappointed in the lack of “background knowledge” that Nora gets while she experiences the “trial life”. I mean who wants to be thrown onto a stage without any song knowledge AND remember she had just committed suicide. What more anxiety can you throw at a person than being on stage (which she hated as a younger person). That’s why 4 stars.
title: Wished they explained what happens to Displace Nora

author: Celeste
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2021
review_content: This book was so fun to read. I think all of us have thought about what life could have been if we made different decisions along the way. The thought that there could be thousands of parallel universes of your life is really intriguing. The key things I took away from this was: have an appreciation for the life you are living today, regardless of how “mundane”, “normal”, “repetitive” it may seem. There is an impact that every person makes on other people around them. There is a reason for every living person.Don’t let regrets be the motivation in your decision making. Figure out what your root motivators are - are you doing things for yourself? Or because you’re trying to fit a mold that someone else thinks you should fit into?There are many other things I’ve taken from this book that I’m sure it will take weeks to unpack. I was sad when it ended!
title: An Intriguing, and thought-provoking read

author: M. L. Larson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: It gets better.  That is entire premise of  book in one sentence.  I was originally going to suggest deletimg first half of the book showing reader how depressed Nora was but then realized it was only 20 pages.  Skip them anyway. The book starts at chapter headed 00:00.Such a great idea for book about multiverses. So disappointing to get formula story telling about depression instead.  But if objective was to help a depressed person I think it fails miserably. Every plot point is so obvious it is ridiculous and condescending to the reader. I skipped pages upon pages of empty preaching.The alternate lives were well written and earned a star.
title: Grudgingly upgraded from two to three  stars

author: Sarynka
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
review_content: I just finished this today after getting it Monday night.I cried like a baby when I finished it. Like, legit bawled.The beginning sucks you in fast, but it's also dark--but not gratuitously. You realize it has to be a bit dark, because everything starts from that place.By a third or so through the book, things get really interesting. Haig has a way of taking a plot line that isn't terribly new, but making it SO so real. And relatable. Nora is a wonderful protagonist, and I find her to be flawed in a way that is really...whole. Her redeeming qualities make me want to be her friend. Her book of regrets is something so many people can see themselves in.It's the kind of book that sticks with you, and when I finished it, I thought, "This is exactly the book I needed right now."Read it. Seriously.
title: Simply lovely. (I bawled.) Excellent pandemic read.

author: Psychologist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: I read this book because I have been going through my latest existential crisis for several months now. I had been reviewing my life as it was around my birthday and my college reunion. I began to see many lost opportunities, and one especially came back to haunt me. I fell into a deep pit of what-ifs and this novel helped me begin to climb out of that deep pit. I cried many times while reading this, but in a good, cleansing sort of way. I highly recommend this book to anyone with a severe case of the "what-ifs."
title: Entertaining and thought-provoking.

author: llc73
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: This book was one of the best books I’ve read in a long time. I originally ordered it on kindle and was so intrigued I also bought the audible version to listen in the car. I then ordered a hard cover copy so that I could read again and underline all of the many brilliant lines that really resonated with me. This book is so timely for many of us who have been doing some soul searching during this crazy year of 2020. In fact, in the two weeks since I finished this book, I have sent it as a gift to 3 people and recommended it to at least 10. We are a culture of the “grass is always greener” and we often get weighed down by the nagging chatter of “what if” and “should have” that cycles around in our heads. When we are in a rut, we tend to allow ourselves to stew over the path we did not take. That illusive path takes on a life of its own as the missed opportunity and we view it through a narrow lens of perfection, failing to think about the potential flaws and hardships. I wish Amazon would reposition the review from Patrick that comes up as a top review, because while I respect his opinion, it is a disservice to this wonderful book to have that be the first review that people see.
title: BEST BOOK of 2020! I have given this as a gift to 3 people!

author: Zoe P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
review_content: Who doesn’t play the ‘Could have ... Should have ... Would have’ game with themselves at times? We all do. Who is free of regret? No one. This book made me rethink so much of my life view. Was so needed given the abundance of time to overthink and question our lives and why we were in the places we were, and what to do with ourselves going forward. Less about suicide and more about life. You don’t need to struggle with mental health issues to be changed by this book. Such a treasure!!!
title: A book to devour and share!

author: Marveymezzo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
review_content: Can Nora's life be redeemed? Every decision, even the most mundane has created a parallel life off of Nora's root life. When she gives up on her life after a period of disappointments and emotional stress, Nora ends up in a place between life and death. It's a library filled with the books of all of these parallel lives. There's an infinite number of books to fall into and experience. I especially liked the heavy book of regrets. Wouldn't it be great to find a way to let go of each regret you've accumulated over the course of your life? And even better, to get excited about living once more!  I enjoyed it very much.
title: Redemption

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2021
review_content: Before buying this book, I had read in some of the reviews that it was predictable. After reading it, I found that yes, it was. The ending was predictable, but that doesn't mean it wasn't a good read. I enjoyed the story and Nora's experience through so many of her possible lives. I enjoyed what she learned along the way, and some of her lessons were applicable to my own life. I have thoughts like "What if I would have...?" and "Would I be happier if...?" even though I am very happy in my real life. But it's interesting to think about anyways, right? Somewhat predictable ending, but since I was reading a book purely for entertainment, and it entertained me, I would definitely recommend this.
title: Quick Read, Gets you Thinking

author: Sunchine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: So, yah, to answer some of the other reviews, it is a little predictable. However! I thought it was a charming story and even though not an up-all-night-to-finish read, it did find it interesting and finished in four days. It reminded me of A Man Called Ove for some reason. Nothing I could put my finger on, just that I enjoyed it and smiled while I was reading it as well. I think it would be a perfect vacation or beach book or just take-a-break-from-life book.
title: Loved it

author: K. Stryker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2021
review_content: When I started to read the first few pages, I wasn’t sure whether I had the emotional strength to get through the whole book. I was pleasantly surprised as I moved through the chapters and I had a difficult time putting this one down! I feel as though I went on the journey with Nora and watched her grow. Life is all about choices and Mrs. Elm was right - whether the decisions you make are small or large, the culmination of those decisions makes you who you are. How many of us are carrying the heavy burden of regret, focused on what could have been? This is a great read for a young adult, or a more mature reader who reflects on their own decisions.
title: Wow

author: Linda S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2021
review_content: The protagonist is offered choices in the form of books in her own Midnight Library to see how life would have been if subtle changes had occurred.  Interestingly, things didn't always work out as she thought they might.  The Library appeared when she had decided to take her own life which was to her no longer worth living.  Through trying different versions of how her life might have been, she came to realize the one she had was not as bad as she thought ... the grass was not greener on the other side.  Interesting characters and situations.  Interesting concept as we all wonder about our choices.
title: Choices we make have far reaching effects, but perhaps seeing the outcomes of different choices ...

author: Marian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: Regrets. They are sad things that everyone possesses. In this novel regrets can pivot you into an entirely new life. This is a really good argument against suicide. It is a really good argument to appreciate the life you have and to make the best of it.
title: A very special library

author: Bec14
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2021
review_content: Every now and then, you find the book on the shelf that doesn't burn... The kind that makes you smile, cry, sometimes both at the same time. The one that crosses between outstanding prose and beautiful poetry. One where you have to stop and reread a sentence slowly because the words in the particular way they are strung together are beautifully lyrical. And when you are finished reading the book, you feel like you'll be missing a friend. The Midnight Library is one of those extraordinary books. It will stay with you forever, I promise!
title: Exceptional

author: Taylor McMillion
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: It has taken me a bit to write this review and I think it’s because in order to really get the full effect of the book, you need some time to process. If you are not in the mood or the right frame of mind for a deeply profound and heavy story, don’t read this book yet. Wait until you can really take it all in.Between life and death there is a library, and wishing that library are an infinite number of books representing an infinite amount of pathways your life could have taken had you made any decision in your life differently. Would you do anything over if you had the chance to undo things you regret about your life?First of all, I have to give a big fat TRIGGER WARNING on this book as it delves deeply into depression, suicide, drug overdose, death of loved ones, feelings of extreme isolation, and a profound sense of regret. The first 25 pages are especially heavy in the suicide department and I had to actually stop reading it for a day to recover. Once you’re past that point, it’s “lightly” (I put that in quotes because it’s obviously not a light topic, but it isn’t as prominent of a theme) mentioned a few more times, but wasn’t nearly as difficult to get through.Second of all, this needs to be a book that you read in your lifetime. It really puts a lot of important things about life into perspective, including the following:1. Things are not always what they seem2. Every choice we make has both good and bad consequences, whether we are aware of those consequences or not3. Regretting choices you’ve made in your life changes nothing, just find a way to move past it and make a change moving forward.I told you, some seriously heavy stuff. And all packed into about 280. I loved everything about The Midnight Library though and would 1,000,000/10 recommend.
title: Amazing book everyone should read

author: Steve Heston
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2021
review_content: A friend recommended this book to me under rather random circumstances about 72 hours ago. I began reading that night and finished it in less than three days. If you are in or have been in transition, this book will bring clarity. If you are in or have been in doubt, this book will bring comfort. If you are or have been confused, This book will bring perspective. The Midnight Library has been a gift, a blessing and the perfect read at the perfect time!
title: There Are No Coincidences

author: Emily
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
review_content: Nora Seed believes she has nothing left to live for and decides to end her life.  What she doesn't expect is to have her path put her on a different path one where she can choose the type of life she may want, but will she find what she is looking for?This was different then what I usually read, I have to say it was pretty good.  I liked the idea of getting a second chance or two at what if's.  I thought this was well written and takes a heavy subject and has Nora exploring possibilities all the while remembering her life the way it was.  Definitely made you think.
title: Intriguing story

author: SWagner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: Sometimes you pick up a book and you’re not sure what it will be. This book was an old friend, a teacher and a spidery web of the paths not taken. I loved this book. A lot like the movie Sliding Doors — but so much better. This is the story of Nora starting when she’s given up, but taking you through all of the what if’s and possibilities. Worth a read for anyone at a cross roads or just feeling tired of life. Coming out of a year of shut downs with the pandemic, this hit me at the perfect time to reevaluate what I want and need right now.
title: Lovely. A life worth living. Actually many of them.

author: Ex-Pat Brit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: I vacillated between giving more or fewer stars, but settled on the middle. I read the great reviews and found the premise intriguing. After finding myself #400 on the hold list at the library, I gave in and bought the book. I did enjoy reading the book. Really. The book was well written. However, I felt more and more deflated the further I went on the reading journey because I had figured out the plot and plot twists. Any surprises? Nope. At the end of the book I felt dazed and flat, stunned by the absence of novelty or surprise. But I had still enjoyed the journey.
title: Predictable, but I enjoyed the journey

author: LML
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2021
review_content: I'm an avid reader but have been rather dismayed by the stories I've been reading.  Simply run of the mill - story lines often told and repeated in a slightly different way.  HOWEVER, this particular book is mesmerizing.  Simply for the fact that it is so innovative, all-encompassing.  The writing is superb.  The lessons are to take with you throughout life - stellar philosophizing!  I'm so enthralled with this book that I'm about to order all of Haig's other books.  I intend to be an avid fan!  PLEASE.....read this book carefully.  So many interesting messages!
title: A Book You WILL remember!

author: OS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: It is definitely not a literary masterpiece, but the book contains some very good existential ideas and managed to get me thinking. The story overall is touching and hopeful, there is an interesting development with plenty of very emotional moments. Didn’t feel very strongly about the main character as she was all over the place. He tried a bit too hard to portray her as this complex many-sided individual, but ended up feeling very surface-ish. The writing felt very unpolished and uneven like it was his first draft. But it was very easy and light to read (especially useful to unwind before going to bed).Still an okay book to get distracted and not overwhelm yourself with complex ideas.
title: Good ideas, not the best execution.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2021
review_content: Nora Seed had enough if it, her life is a mess and she finds the easiest and yet the unacceptable fate to end her life. That's when Mrs Elm supports her to find her the best life out of infinite possibilities. Which fate will be the final? Is there any fate which ignite the passion to feel alive... That's what you have to find.Read this over few days. Love the concept and the layout. This book delivers basic philosophy in simplest terms. This book is great for anyone to get a glimpse of a depressed person's mind or going through a rough phase in life...
title: Do you have chances to reset if you life is at an extreme destitution

author: Laken Oliver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: It started out depressing.  And I swear, even through the many lives she had, while she learned lessons, she never seemed to realize  where her true happiness lies.  And so... it was just really monotone in nature.  Everything just seemed sad in this book.  The ending needed much more to really express the point of life and living.As someone who suffers with depression and anxiety... I do have to wonder after reading this book, what are my life regrets?  And how on earth can one be so afraid of death, yet want it so much?The book did get me thinking.  So I guess there is somewhat of a redeeming quality there.
title: Could've been something much better.

author: DANIELLE
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: I honestly bought this book due to the almost five stars I had seen. I failed to actually read the reviews which was my mistake. It was quite depressing and I would not advise anyone who suffers from depression or with suicidal thoughts to read this. I didn’t get far in this book maybe within the first 20pgs and I gave up. I may try to readdress it at another time but any person that envies their dead cat, not really a book I want to read. I thought it was more about if you could live other lives what would you do or be kind of thing. Again, I will possibly read it at a later date but not tonight:(
title: Disappointed

author: A reader from Connecticut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2021
review_content: It reads as though the author found an outline to ‘hang his hat on’ and filled in vignettes to prove his preordained outcome.  It served to complicate the storyline when he worked to fit in different characters from other vignettes to show the role they did or didn’t play in other choices Nora might have made with her life story. The chapters were brief with a lot of blank paper at the end of a vignette or chapter, which made the book look like it was longer and had more content than it really had.  It’s not the kind of book I would give to a friend or ever reread.
title: Very formulaic, stock characters

author: Author & Book Lover
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
review_content: I found out about this book when it was reviewed on The Jason Show in Minneapolis. I was immediately intrigued and could not put it down. It's about a library that appears in the phase between life and death. The main character gets to try all kinds of alternate versions of her life and ultimately decide which one she likes best and if that is enough to make her want to live and create the life she wants.It was amazing and I'll be recommmending this book to everyone I know that reads.Thank you for this beautiful book, Matt Haig.
title: Eye Opening (Story Spoiler)

author: JenMog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: I had a little trouble getting into Nora and her story, but I love Matt Haig and I love parallel universe stories, so I stuck with it and I’m REALLY glad that I did. Rich and layered characters, an imaginative plot, and a satisfying conclusion (even if I could see it coming a little bit). Definitely worth the read. Haig’s other works of fiction are also fantastic!
title: Love Matt Haig. Will read anything he writes.

author: VICKY
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2021
review_content: Unreal. Going back to re visit serious decisions the main character made in life is surprisingly believable and fascinating. It made me rethink a divorce from 50 years ago and come away less frustrated. I enjoyed reliving the main character’s possible lives with her. This book was recommended by a fellow dog walker so I nearly forgot it but there was something about his enthusiasm that got me intrigued so I bought it. It is a rare find for me. I seriously recommend that any reader get past the beginning in order to feast on the middle and end.
title: Wow I am so pleased that I “ took a chance” with this book

author: BLK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2021
review_content: Such a beautiful story! The main character begins as a depressed, forlorn woman, who has lost her job, lost her cat, and lost her brother. She is given the opportunity to experience life based on a variety of different choices. She learns how her choices not only affect herself, but also others. Through the character’s experiences, the author creates a clear message about how one’s perspective affects one’s happiness. You cannot read it without reflecting on your own regrets in life and thinking about how your own perspective towards your life choices has affected your own happiness.
title: Love this book!!!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2020
review_content: Sometimes a friend chooses a book for your book club that you might not be excited about. That how I felt when she chose this one. But the ultimate lessons and the delightful way in which they are presented kept me entranced all the way through. Nora has to jump into many lives to learn what matters most. And the lives she lives are always worth living.
title: The book I wanted to read without knowing I needed to read it

author: Deborah Allgeier
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review_content: I just read “The Midnight Library” by Matt Haig.  This book was great!  It’s a quirky mix of life’s choices, situational depression, quantum physics, family expectations, parallel universes, and real life angst and regret.  This is Haig’s latest book, yet I had either never heard of him and/or paid little attention to his other works.  This book is a positive, uplifting story of one woman’s amazing journey through snippets of many alternative lifetimes at the midnight library.  I will be reading more of Haig. Meantime, I highly recommend this one. 📚📚📚📚📚
title: The Midnight Library

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: I would actually give 4 1/2 stars.  It was not a perfect book.  You really have to buy in to the contrived (?) premise, and not be disturbed with the suicidal character at the beginning of the book.  But I DID enjoy this book.  It reminded me of the TV show The Good Place, which I loved, which was also an entertaining philosophy for dummies.  Yes, it had a rather predictable path and ending, but it was a journey I enjoyed being on, not one I was bored with - there's a difference.  And there were a few passages I flagged as real gems.
title: Entertaining philosophy for dummies in a good way

author: C. Tankersley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021
review_content: At first when I started reading this book, I thought it might be a bit depressing. But it was anything but depressing. Full of hope and some insight to people who might have clinical depression and why. I tend to be pretty optimistic so it’s hard for me to understand depression. Life seems to be full of so many options and choices that are exciting. I don’t really think about what could’ve been. I don’t really regret. This book was not preachy nor grandstanding as some have said. Just go into it with an open mind and enjoy the story.
title: Very Interesting Read

author: Fancy Allen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
review_content: I found Matt many years ago in the back of Entertainment Weekly as a suggested summer book to read called The Radley's and I've been hooked since.Each novel takes you in a different different, not knowing what to expect and never letting you down.The Midnight Library is no different. I found that I had to physically put it down so I could savor it more. Matt invests in every character and I always feel that I've become one with book. I'm sad it over, but I can imagine how the story ends, or continues. Xoxo
title: Once again, I'm blown away.

author: Rachel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2021
review_content: Haig took such a tragic situation and turned into a loveable and beautiful book. I wasn't sure what to expect after reading the synopsis, but I loved this take on suicide and one's choice to end their own life. Watching Nora go through her different options and seeing how different things happen based on just one choice or one regret was really a lesson that we can all take and apply it to our own lives in everyday. I wasn't crazy about the ending, but it was wrapped up nicely and loved every second in between the beginning and the end.
title: One decision can change your entire life

author: DJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2021
review_content: This is a moment-of-death fable in the spirit and style of Mitch Albom’s “The Five People You Meet in Heaven” (in fact, both stories begin with a clock counting down to the death of the protagonist). I enjoyed the story. But it’s not very deep and is a bit too predictable: a third of the way through the book you’ll see the broad outlines of the plot all the way to the unsurprising ending. The details along the way did make the journey interesting and worthwhile. And I didn’t want the story the end – the ultimate measure of a good book. But I can’t shake the feeling that the author could have done more with the premise.
title: Not bad, but a bit predictable

author: Gabriela Delgado
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2020
review_content: This is strictly on the condition of the book. I was so disappointed when I opened the box and saw that there was something off about the book. When I opened it the first pages were separating. I didn’t expect a brand new book to be in such poor condition. It was meant to be a present so I wouldn’t have had time to exchange it for a replacement. I should’ve just gone to B&N to buy the book in the first place for an extra $3.
title: You get what you pay

author: D. Isherwood
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2021
review_content: I didn’t expect to like this as much as I did. Like Recursion by Blake Crouch this book focuses on “what might have been.”  I love books that get me thinking about the high and low points of life and what I might change were I given the chance. The message in this is different than Recursion but both books stuck with me long after I finished them.The library as the clearinghouse for all different life paths was a great metaphor.This is a quick read and one of the best books I’ve read in awhile. Highly recommend it.
title: Loved it

author: Rashi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: I really like the writing style, the story, the characters, and the imageries associated with this novel. I read it as part of a book club and unfortunately, the other members did not enjoy this book as much as I did. But, I think I especially enjoyed it because of how much I was able to resonate w/ the main character - Nora. Matt Haig is an extremely talented writer who really understands human emotion. I really enjoyed the concept of having a library as a state of limbo between life & death. I highly recommend this novel!
title: Quick, easy, and fun read

author: Katie Bee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library by Matt Haig🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟What a fantastic story and unique concept. Every once in a while I wonder what my life would be like had  I made a different choice or an event happened. What if I never left NY? What would my life have been like had my mom never met my awesome step dad? What if dad hadn't retired from the air force? Had I pursued a degree in theater. In this book Nora gets to live out those kinds of questions in her life, go back and fix her regrets. She finds out the only way to learn is live and to never under estimate the big importance of small things.📖📖📖📖Trigger warnings: suicide, grief, and depression
title: Fascinating concept about life.

author: histfictjunkie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: I LOVED this book. I loved the philosophy and the idea of parallel universes. I loved the idea of the library and “trying on” different lives. I love how the different lives help Nora heal the hurts of her past and realize that she does have the strength in her to keep going. In the end, what we have is our current life and it’s up to us what we will do with it: hang on to regrets or find new strength to press forward and create a new and better future. It’s not a new idea, but I found it a refreshing and new take on a timeless concept.
title: Beautiful and Powerful

author: Alicia J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: As a therapist in training, I THOROUGHLY ENJOYED THIS BOOK !!! The synopsis didn’t prepare me for what to expect and I’M GLAD it didn’t !Loved the take on the midnight library and the lesson in the end.A MUST READ !!!
title: Amazing Read

author: K. Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2020
review_content: I enjoyed reading every word. It’s about the protagonist and her regrets over missed opportunities and dissatisfaction with her current life. The main character gets an opportunity to live other lives (parallel lives vs time travel). She learns through experience how it’s not about the big regrets, but the little things you don’t think of that influences how you think and feel (and it’s affect on others). It’s about coming to terms with what you have, versus what you don’t have or think you want - and are you making choices for yourself or what you think others want for you? It’s also about depression and is enjoyable to read with humor and insight. I loved all the details and references and how it all came together. It can be a breezy read or a heavier read depending on what you want to get out of it. Kind of like ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’ and it met ALL my expectations!
title: Propulsive and thoughtful

author: Tasha O.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: I just want to preface this review by stating that this is a fictional book! Not a self help non fiction philosophical book. Please seek professional help, as this book is not going to provide you with a clinical game plan on how to manage your depression or make you non-suicidal. It is a feel good book to lift your spirits, and give you hope (see attachment). Additionally, suicide and depressions looks different to different people!!! Please don't read this fictional book thinking it's going to perfectly describe how depression and suicide looks/feels like for every single person on this planet.To start, I believe the author doesn't give you a full on visual of what this character looks like because when some people are suicidal/depressed, you can't even see yourself clearly and feel like an unimportant irrelevant shadow. I like how there wasn't much descriptive language (hair color, eye color, skin tone, etc) because suicide and depression isn't exclusive to just one 'look'.Throughout this novel, Nora is allowed to essentially live a regret (ie what would have happened if I stuck with swimming, became a pop star, traveled/live x, married x), and would come back to the library when she felt disappointed in that 'life'. The whole point of this was to broadcast how we thinking doing x would led us to live a perfect happy life, when perfect life is impossible. Even when you get everything you want, there are still going to be negatives. I know I get caught up thinking about how my life would have been perfect if I did or said xy&z, when in reality, it probably wouldn't have been as perfect as I thought it would be. In these alternative lives were she got what she wanted, she realizes all the sacrifices that she had to make or give up that she didn't think she would, and how everything wasn't sunshine and rainbows like she thought it was going to be.Lastly, I thought this book also highlights the butterfly effect really well. I often overlook the everyday small and mundane things I do, and feel like I don't always make a huge difference (esp. with quarantine). In the book, it shows how her teaching piano for an hour with one student has a bigger impact on his life than she thought. For me, I felt it highlighted how things would have obviously been different if she made different decisions, but the life she was living wasn't as worthless as she thought, and it was something worth fighting for.I read this book in one night (it's 288 pages), and would highly recommend!
title: IGNORE TOP REVIEWS

author: E. P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2021
review_content: This is the second, and likely last, book by Matt Haig I read. In both books I found the author instills some social cause into the narrative, I found that irritating. Can you just read a book for entertainment anymore? Also, I could not warm up to the main character, whom I found on the whiny side, and the moral at the end is quite predictable. I knew the topic of living different lives based on different choices has been discussed ad nauseam, so I was naive in expecting something beside a cliché.
title: Unsatisfactory

author: Stephen Chavez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
review_content: Who hasn't, at times, wondered whether we are living up to our full potential, or wondered why the social media posts of others seemed so much more exciting and fulfilling than ours? The Midnight Library is a fun read about the directions our lives could have taken had our choices been slightly different. The book is a slightly more complicated modern retelling of fantasy tales such as The Wizard of Oz. Like that story, readers are treated to a sympathetic protagonist and a credible and colorful supporting cast. I enjoyed the journey,because it led me right where I hoped it would.
title: The Time of Your Life

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: Personally, I didn’t like it as a fiction novel. I thought the plot lacked creativity, and Nora’s character just seemed like a passive placeholder. I hated how spoon-fed the reader was. We didn’t get to come to any of our own conclusions, bc the story was SO straightforward. The premise of the book is SO cool... but sadly executed. And super redundant. By the end I felt like I was being beaten over the head with the same ideas.Now, as a self-help novel, it was kinda quirky. I can see why so many people enjoy it. I’ll definitely be recommending it to other people. I did like the overall message that love brings meaning and significance. And I’m gonna hang onto “it’s not what you’re looking at but how you look at it.”
title: Poor fiction/Okay self-help

author: Prismpromise
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2021
review_content: This was one of very few books I could not continue reading. I actually returned it. I was unable to read through the depressing progression of a woman’s suicide spiral. While I recognize that the offensive (to me) language and content is a cultural norm at this point in time, I do not wish to immerse myself in it.
title: Not for me.

author: pierce scranton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: The pretext is unbelievable. A total loser that everyone hates determines to kill herself. Gunshot? Hanging? Drugs? We don’t know. But now the mysterious librarian gives her a chance to open a book and rewrite her life. In fact, many chances.Sorry, too far fetched. Didn’t bother with the ending because the beginning was so bad .
title: Was this self published????

author: Andre M. Behrens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
review_content: This book has a lot of emotion, an interesting premise, some wrenching scenes, some fluffy imagery, and consistent, readable writing. I quickly got lost in it’s rhythm, and never got pulled out of the flow. For a high-concept story, the concept never got in the way of the story or my enjoyment of it. The protagonist faces legitimate challenges. The growth process is interesting and well paced. There is a story, not just a plot. And the ending delivers.Excellent read, recommended.
title: A thinky fantasy that sticks the landing.

author: Ann-Marie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: I really tried to like it but just couldn't get into it. I felt like there was a lot i was missing because I wasn't trying to find the symbolism in every paragraph. The main character was so lacking any whiny. No feel good ending for me.
title: Very disappointed

author: anndroid
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2021
review_content: I rarely take time to write a review but after just finishing and turning the last page of The Midnight Library, I feel compelled to share a review.I LOVED this book! Depending where you are on your journey in this life, this book may or may not speak to you but for me, it showed up just when I needed it most.These days, it’s not often that I find a fiction book outside of a classic novel, that truly engages me. This book isn’t a complicated read. It’s simply a story of a young woman who finds herself lost and holding onto lots of regret. The story shares a timeless and welcomed reminder of how precious this one life we have is.I personally related to the story and the struggle to appreciate not only what we have but more importantly, who we are and our value in this life. Every decision we make or don’t make has an impact and unlike Nora, the main character, we will most likely never know the far-reaching consequences of all our choices but we can be assured that every choice matters as well as every thought.The “story” we tell ourselves about ourselves isn’t always truth and sadly, the story is often someone else’s story that we took on as our own.  The beauty of this life is that we always have the choice to change our perspective. We can choose to see light or dark, truth or untruth. Each moment we can rewrite our story.Thank you Matt Haig for this beautiful story that reminds us all that it’s love that gives us purpose and meaning in this life.
title: Exactly what I needed!

author: The Slow Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2021
review_content: Other people make bucket lists; I make lists (in my mind) of books to take to a desert island.  I would definitely not take this book.  It broadcast its ending almost from the first pages.  The characters seemed living in a boring way ... that isn’t clear ... the characters seemed predictable sounds better.  Spoiler alert!  Through the whole book I kept humming “Be it ever so humble, there’s no place like home.”  On the positive side, Mrs Elm is a wonderful librarian.  But, on balance, this book held no surprises and left this reader feeling it was a waste of time.
title: Would ai take this book from the Midnight Library

author: Ros
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: I was blown away with the quantum physics Theory And how many lives we could live in parallel at a time But the story of the girl was not that compelling to me. I was expecting her To meet special people on her journey and basically have more twists in each life but it was plain simple and predictable.
title: The quantum physics theory made it an interesting read But overall it was okay

author: Danielle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021
review_content: I enjoyed up until the end where her happiness was being married and having a baby as if that’s what makes all women happy. And the self help books suggested at the end.
title: Review has spoiler

author: Christine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2021
review_content: Could maybe lean over three stars but not enough to bump to four.I didn’t really care for the main protagonist and preferred Mrs Elm a lot more. Her whiny, it’s not fair, lack of realization and thought just made her unlikable. I wanted to slap her sometimes.The redundancy and thought of the premise of this book bothered me a little bit...Still it was well written... good story developed... and ended well. (Although kind of expected)
title: Choices, regrets, parallel universe with the liking of Groundhog Day

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: Finding a live, a good life is so difficult. And you must want it even if it is not exactly perfect. Because you know it haspotential. I never found mine, maybe Nora will. At times I felt lost, even bored by this book. But I finished it. For me there is no love, but I will manage to live this life through.
title: I want to live

author: Julie P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2020
review_content: I had trouble getting through the book.  I wasn’t enamored of the main character and the premise stretched thin about a third of the way through.  It was well written though.
title: A little tedious

author: Henry Huta
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
review_content: The last few chapters are basically "It's a Wonderful Life". I wish it had been fleshed out more after she survived her suicide attempt.
title: Disappointed

author: Patricia Horanberg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: When I first started the book I wasn’t really sure where it was going but I had already bought my ticket so I was going to ride all the stops - it was like opening a gift that has a box within a box within a box ad infinitum but instead of each box being the same they became more intricate and detailed until the final box - and yet you saw that each box was a gift on its own. I finished it in one sitting and the story is one of those that will stay with me for a while.
title: A chance to be thankful

author: Karen Henson Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: I loved this book! Typical to Matt Haig's style, the author weaves in the most unexpected jokes that make you laugh and cry at just the right moments. This book is super clever, and just the balm we all need today. This book helps you to appreciate your authentic self and make peace with past choices. Recommend highly! Karen Henson Jones
title: Phenomenal book

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
review_content: Wow! I just finished this and I am in awe.  From the first page this book resonated with me. It hit home in so many ways that there is not enough room to tell you how. I could be Nora except for the wanting to die part. I have just recently decided to do things for me and that bring me joy and not be who others think I should be or do. I have regrets but I now own them. The choices were mine and have brought me to where I am now "warts" and all. I am glad I had this book.
title: What a Read

author: Kate
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: “The Midnight Library” was an enthralling read. Starting out on a somber note, the novel quickly dove into the depths of human existence and the regrets and “what-ifs” we all have. At the core of the novel is the belief that our past regrets do not define us, that there is always opportunity to redefine our now. As someone who has experienced feeling “stuck” before, I could appreciate Nora’s journey to falling in love with life as it happens.
title: Leaves You Pondering Life’s Unturned Pages

author: Jennifer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: This book has heavy depression themes and involves the main character actually committing suicide. I'm sorry if that ruins the book, but I'm surprised more reviews don't state this? The synopsis doesn't really give off that information either. As someone who is pregnant and dealing with severe depression it was a little triggering and I probably wouldn't have started reading it in my state of mind.I put it down to read for a better time, but I've enjoyed most of it! Like other reviews have stated the author does say the same thing about life but in a different way many times. Its a little annoying.
title: **Trigger Warning** Depression & Suicide

author: Jalina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2021
review_content: I did enjoy this book. It was a quuck read, and i felt really explained depression well, and how to avoid that stuck feelng. Its very easy (almost too easy) to insert your self as the main character, and feel the similarity of regrets.I really enjoyed the quotes that were in the book. I also liked that the book ended on an almond cliffhanger. Not as an enticement to buy a second book, but to really drill home the point that the opportunities and possibilities were, and are, endless.But more often than not, i felt like the author needed to chill with the thesaurus. I understand her knowledge was ment to make her more different and outcastish. I was very frustrated with the amount of times it seemed that Nora knew everything, And then seconds later knew nothing.
title: Very good young adult book for someone who might need advice on seeking other perspectives

author: Cindylouwho
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: The author depicts depression so realistically, I felt drawn into the black hole with the main character. I almost stopped reading because it was so oppressive. But I got caught up in the story, the multiple characters, the quips from various philosophers, with a fantasy element of multiple lives, quantum physics, and self reflection, I enjoyed the insight from the main character through her self discovery. A good read. Glad I kept going.
title: Desperate depression evolves to love for life

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: I hate to rag on a book, authors put their heart an soul into them.  But I didn’t enjoy this book despite the rave reviews.  It just didn’t grab me and I never finished it.  I think it might be a nice little escapist read for maybe... a younger adult?  Plot development isn’t sophisticated and somehow it reminds me of Bridget Jones books.  Cutesy, simple.  Not great.
title: Doesn’t match the hype

author: Rebecca H. Augustine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: Have you ever wanted to have a "redo" or maybe many of the irrevocable wrongs you have done?  Or maybe one decision you made wasn't so bad, but it might not have been the best, and you have always asked yourself, "What if I had made the other choice?" Nora Seed, a woman "in-between life and death," gets the opportunity to experience the consequences of decisions she might have made through the agency of Mrs. Elm of the Midnight Library.
title: A Great "What If" Book

author: girlfriend 11
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
review_content: ..and while it's not Bedford Falls, it IS Bedford.  This book is a parable,one that has already been told.  I didn't find it to be fresh or new in any way.  I read it to the end, wondering if the ending would provide a surprise, but it did not.  It was boring and disappointing
title: It's Wonderful Life Spoiler alert

author: Katherine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2021
review_content: This is an engaging theme, story and philosophical question.  What if you could explore other life paths in a do over?  I like the main character although I think she needs counseling and a kick in the pants. It is part “dark amusement “, not LOL comedy. I have not finished reading so I reserve final judgement on whether I find it totally satisfying but at this time I am thinking of people who should read this book which translates into I recommend the book.
title: Recommending this reflection o life do over

author: Jessy Munch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
review_content: I loved this book. I usually don’t read non fiction but this was great and so relevant in life. There are always so many what if’s and what if I chose a different route, what would happen. This book explores that and it’s a great perspective to think about. I loved the story line, it was greatly written. Highly recommend this book and now I am reading the authors Memoir. Glad I did a book club that had this book as the reading.
title: So good and relatable to life

author: stephanie martinez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2021
review_content: I didn’t realize this book was by Matt Haig until I finished it, but I could tell. How To Stop Time has the same evolution in the idea of life.I started this book because of a Bookstagram but stayed because of the story. The first few chapters when she contemplates suicide are so well written it almost *makes sense* she wants to kill herself. Don’t get me wrong, suicide is horrible, but her emotions and loneliness are so real, I could feel the cold of her empty apartment. I could feel her despair and feel her wanting to live slowly disappear.Nora is a very relatable character. Full of regrets. Things she wished she did differently in life. Funny how when we get the chance to fix them, they don’t look as much as regrets anymore.
title: Wow

author: CKD!
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
review_content: I will start by saying this is not my typical book. I was a book club mediator and this was the chosen book. I like a book that makes you think and that definitely happens here. How do our choices change our lives and others? Matt shows us many different ways that Nora's choices did. I will say I guess the end result but getting there was still good. If you are iffy about reading this novel, pick it up and give it a try.
title: How do our chooses change our life?

author: Hayley Byrnes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: I picked this book for my book club and the description sounded really interesting.  The idea was intriguing.I did not know the main character needed to commit suicide to access the library.I myself have dealt with intrusive suicidal thoughts and I was having a bad mental health week and this was not the great escape novel I was looking for.I felt obligated to finish the book because I bought it and it was also for a book club that I picked the book for, and I hated it.  The story was predictable, and like other reviewers have said, super condescending to people who have actually struggled with depression.Pick something else.  There is no reason for this to be a best-seller right now.  Especially since the premise isn't fully explained in the book's description.
title: The Description Needed a Trigger Warning for Suicide

author: Jonathan Gemini
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: Premise is a little precious, but the story is engaging and I found myself reading quickly despite the occasional eye roll.I realized that it's really a book about decisions and commitment, not the meaning or value of life.I can relate to this bc I'm a gemini with a strong inclination to what-if everything.So if you want a book about the meaning of life, this isn't it, but if you enjoy a romp through a world of what ifs, then enjoy!
title: Liked it more than I expected

author: Claire Lynch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: For anyone who might have wondered “if only” or “I wonder what would have happened...”  Nora decides her life is not worth living, so in the “in between” space of the midnight library, she explores the lives she might have lived if she had made different choices. She learns a great deal about those people close to her, and realizes the impacts she had on the lives of others. There are elements of “Its a Wonderful Life”, but she learns the value of choosing to live her own life. I closed the book regretfully, and have a new mantra, “There are no bad choices. Live with no regrets”.
title: What might have been...

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
review_content: Ever wonder what life would’ve been without you in it?  Ever wonder what your life could’ve been if you had made different choices?  This book looks at both these scenarios.  Yes, this type of narrative has been played out before in both movies and books.  Yes, I knew exactly how it would end before finishing the first chapter.  Yes, it became trite and preach-ey, the narrative losing subtlety as it dragged on.  Rather than allowing the reader to come to our own insights, Haig beats his insights into us by saying the same thing over and over via far too many analogies, metaphors, and famous quotes.  Still and all, I did enjoy it.  I would’ve enjoyed it more had it been a short story, written tighter and had more openness to let the reader in, but even with the book’s faults, it was a fast and good read.
title: “It’s A Wonderful Life” meets “Sliding Doors”.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2021
review_content: I found this book's casual treatment of suicide ideation thoughtless, careless and uncomfortable.  The author tried to make light of it, as if it were a joke.  Unacceptable.  I do not recommend this book.
title: making light of suicide ideation

author: J. Rafuse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: This book messed with my sense of self a little bit. I found myself questioning a lot in this book and I'm not sure those questions were answered; but I did enjoy the book. It's definitely a "moral of the story" kind of read, such is different from a lot of books I've read lately. I would recommend this book, but I would just warn to make sure you're in a good head space, or at least prepared for some mind messing.
title: oh the places you'll go

author: Sheila K. Smock
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
review_content: This is an unusual read.  At first I wasn't sure I liked the premise  of the book but the more I read,the more it challenged my thinking about the decisions I could have made in life. I thought about all the roads not taken. It  reaffirmed the decisions I did make.  I made mistakes but have no regrets.
title: Thought provoking

author: Jan M Collins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2021
review_content: I knew of this book several months before I actually read it. It is a great story about the infinite possibilities a person has in life. In the book Nora Seed depressed and tired of life finds herself in The Midnight Library when there are endless choices and opportunities to find the perfect life. She learns many lessons in the library.I give this book 5 stars because as soon as I finished I turned around and read it again.
title: Great Premise, Great Read

author: Stephen Parker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: It has been a long time since I sat down and read a book cover-to-cover in one sitting, but that’s what I did with this one. Who hasn’t wondered “what if I had made a different choice” and fantasized about the life they may be leading if they had? And that is the brilliance of this simple premise. I won’t give away any spoilers, but I will say that I truly enjoyed seeing how Nora fared in each of her many lives. The final resolution to the book left my heart soaring for her and for all of us “wonderers”.I highly recommend this novel to anyone interested in a good fiction story.
title: Fabulous. Could not put it down.

author: María Paiz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2021
review_content: I absolutely loved this book. Couldn't put it down! It's a glorious tale of life. I was originally attracted to it because I had read an excerpt of the book about regrets. It really resonated with me because, in some ways, I feel like I'm lost potential. Reading this book was a balm to soothe those nasty feelings and to bring perspective of what life still is and could be. I'll come back to it again to appreciate the wisdom in the pages!
title: Beautiful

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: The choice to live is much more difficult then to just give up.  This book shows us that life can be so difficult with all its ups and downs. For some of us the downs happen much more frequently. But we all write our own futures. What we write is the important thing. I love all the lives Nora experienced in her struggle. What I loved the most is how she chose where to land. For me this one was enlightening. Thank you to the author.
title: Live

author: Salander Lover
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2021
review_content: This novel was an adventure through different lives from the perspective of a frustratingly negative protagonist who gradually learns lessons.  There was a good story arc here, but perhaps because I didn't love the main character, it didn't move me the way it should.  The story is abovr average but not great, unless perhaps you are someone in a stuck or depressed place who really needs a story just like this.
title: Thought provoking

author: Shelley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
review_content: I  LOVED this book. If you have ever had any regrets about your life and wondered what your life would be like if you made different decisions, this book is for you. Extremely well written, and engaging. I couldn't put it down and when I did put it down, I thought about the book, and thought about my life. I normally like books that are 300 pages or under, this one I wish was longer. I did not want it to end.
title: Can't Stop Thinking About This Book

author: Arielle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2020
review_content: I never leave book reviews, but this one calls for it. You can see the ending from outer space, and yet, I couldn’t put this book down! If you’re someone who dwells in “what if’s” and wonders how life might have been, you will enjoy this book. The author captures moments of all emotions and walks of life. By the end, I felt satisfied that I’d visited numerous life alternatives of my own.The writing is great, too.
title: Introspective and Relatable

author: Terry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review_content: I LOVED this book and have never read anything like this. This is the story of Nora Seed, who thought herself a failure, and wanted to dieUntil she visited the Midnight Library and read The Book of Regrets and spirited through parallel lives trying to discover where she belonged.  This story is an adventure like no other. I read all the time, but this one is special, and I’ll never forget it. Enjoy!
title: Outstanding, Unusual, Philosophical but Fun

author: Kimberly Gamauf
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
review_content: The story line of this book is intriguing. Being a time traveler Nora is learning all sorts of knowledge about her lives and ends up turning this knowledge into a sort of wisdom. She calls on it when she sees her life from her own perspective, leaving others perspectives behind. Her thoughts and the life lessons she learns stirred thoughts about my own life. It’s moving, beautiful and laced with gratitude.
title: I couldn’t stop reading......

author: J.J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2021
review_content: I hate reviews with spoilers. I would describe this as a sci fi version of "It's  a Wonderful Life." So yes, a little predictable in places, but not entirely.  Normally I can't stand predictability in anything; I would take off at least one star for that.  But maybe because I picked it up in the first days of 2021, with a hideously unpredictable 2020 comfortably in the rear view mirror, I found comfort in it. Enjoyable if you just go with it.
title: No Spoilers

author: GJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review_content: I found The Midnight Library to be an interesting novel with a clever plot -- the chance to try out different versions of your life until you find one you really like.  However, I felt it the end, while satisfying, was to me predictable.
title: Interesting but not compelling

author: Carol M. Kimball
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: Coming to the edge, Nora has a rare opportunity to see the paths not taken, to test those destinations, and to review her own regrets. The author takes us through a process of how we affect others and ourselves, how we need each other and how we have the power to effect change in positive ways. Our root self has the capability to clear the road of regrets and dance to our own music down our chosen path. The author, Matt Haig does a wonderful weaving so we wink and nod and see the light at the end of our own tunnel vision so we can make those necessary adaptive positive chances.
title: A book to remind us to make the most of our one life.

author: Teresa L. Young
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2021
review_content: Isn't it amazing that when it comes right down to it, the thing we miss most of all is the idea of life?  This book is basically about trying to fit the proverbial square peg into the round hole. You can get it in there but nothing about it will be right. It's only when the opportunity to try it disappears that the appreciation for the opportunity appears. Reading this book was illuminating.
title: The life that matters

author: Annamaria
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: Imagine if you could try on alternate lives until you found the right fit? All the could have, should have decisions are your to make. That is the premise of this fascinating story. We all have a Book of Regrets we carry with us, well some of the lucky ones don't. Its a story about human failings, despair & redemption. If you have ever thought "if only" and sighed out loud, this is for you.
title: Interesting.

author: Color and shape
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: If you are someone dealing with the regular ups and downs of life, this will be an uplifting read.If you are someone who has ever dealt with a true clinical mental health disorder, this book will probably be pretty infuriating in a lot of ways.Peddles in some pretty dangerous misconceptions about depression such as, "people are depressed because they don't feel they have love in their lives"  or are focused on their regrets.Missed opportunity to handle things with more nuance.  Postpartum depression, pmdd, bi polar disorder, clinical depression etc? This will only reinforce misperceptions that are so difficult to communicate through with others.
title: Easy read, harmful take on mental health

author: Gaylee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: Really charming book that touched gently yet deeply into the questions and possible regrets we all have in a life fully lived. If you could go back in time, What would you do differently in your life? And the answer is imponderably straightforward- rue nothing. Just live and experience your own life. Each day has the potential to bring surprises, changes. Good fable done creatively and sweetly.
title: Lives and one life

author: Tee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021
review_content: What an engaging read.  I loved the premise, that a suicidal person could have the opportunity to redo past decisions, take a different path, and come to understand the impact of those decisions.  I appreciated that the author included lyrics to the fictitious song "Howl," and how profound those lyrics were.  I plan to recommend this book to my book club, as well as other readers. Nice work, Matt Haig.
title: This book will stay with me a while

author: RMF
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2021
review_content: I have been through depression with thoughts of suicide.  Reading this book let me look at those memories with new eyes.  My book of regrets has almost slipped away, with recurring bouts of depression, and has been rewritten with love and desire to live a good life of my choosing.  I appreciate the author and his work, it made me think about where I am in my own choices.  Thank you.
title: A very good book to read

author: Sagereader2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library is a great novel.  Matt Haig writes beautifully. He writes of life yet unseen and makes you imagine vast possibilities. His writing is unique, clear, and makes you want to live, to find joy in everyday seemingly mundane matters that are not mundane at all.  The Midnight Library is a 5* plus novel. I give it my highest recommendation and urge you to read it now!
title: Fabulous, outstanding

author: Metaprof
