date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2021
review_content: Haig’s novel is a very interesting addition to the spate of multiple universe themed works that seem to have become a genre of its own. It reminds me of the film “Groundhog Day” but with a very significant twist. The various lives of the heroine are artfully described and each “life” becomes an interesting (very) short story of its own. A very engaging read, I highly recommend it.
title: Very Good Entry to the Multi-Universe Genre

author: Jill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2021
review_content: I just don't get it. This book was cheesy for lack of a better term. It was full of cliches that just were repeated over and over. I felt like I was reading something a teenager may have written.  I struggled to finish this book because it just ended up being boring and predictable. I do not recommend.
title: Nope

author: Mrs. Donna L. Doll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: We all have regrets for things we did or did not do but can not change the results of how those choices affected others nor ourselves. All we can do is appreciate what we have and be able to be kind to others.  MATT Haig has written a wonderful novel that challenges the reader to abandon what ifs and do the best you can with the life you have to make it the best one you have. Exciting and suspenseful, the plot led to an ending I  could not wait  to  read to find out what Noras choice would be. A  very thought provoking  read.
title: Once Is Enough

author: Caity Hatteras
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
review_content: What a great book!! Where do we go when we pass, do we arrive right away or is there time to rethink out life decisions? Can we change one step and get a better outcome?  This is an excellent adventure on that final journey.  Absolutely, a favorite read and a joy to read during this pandemic lockdown time.A talented writer like no other I have ever read. Excellent novel to read as well as for a gift.
title: Is it the choices we select or the ones we don’t that create our life?

author: Ronda Rascon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed this book...it was the “book of the month” for my book club. it was somewhat predictable but it really got me thinking about what it would be like if I were able to do as the main character in the book was able to do (not going to spoil it for you!) and this book also inspired me to write an essay for a class I’m taking.  It definitely gets you thinking about your life.
title: Good read

author: Julie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021
review_content: The Midnight Library catches your attention from the start! Why did Nora decide to die? I had to know. And then once I knew, I had to follow her onto the library and the mysteries of all her selves. It’s a reminder of how life, in its fullness, is beautiful if we just look at it the right way. With our regret and with hope for the potential we hold inside us. I thoroughly enjoyed it!
title: Enchanting

author: Courtney McCarthy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2021
review_content: Incredible- I finished it in a day because I couldn’t put it down. Everyone’s considered how their lives would be different if they could change decisions they regret- and Matt Haig has somehow encompassed a wide and complex variety of potential lifetimes that await the willing. This felt like a guide to the age-old question of human purpose, and it left me feeling grateful.
title: Beautiful

author: R. Patrick Baugh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2021
review_content: Who hasn't fantasized about "what if I'd only done X instead of Y?"?  The Midnight Library answers that question for you through Nora Seed and her admittedly not-so-great life - on the brink of her suicide, she finds out that she can jump into any one of a bazillion what-if lives.  Beautifully written, it kept me glued to each page as we explore Nora's many alternate lives.
title: What if???

author: Prof. Centennius
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2021
review_content: This is a parallel universe and alternative lives fantasy about a woman named Nora who has decided to die, but ends up in a library where she is allowed to see what her life would be like had she made different choices. It is a combination of Ground Hog day and It's a Wonderful Life. I enjoyed reading this very much because it deals with the way regret can poison existence.
title: A book about life and how to live it

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: This is the first Matt Haig book that I have read but I will definitely be reading his others. Haig knows what it’s like to live with regrets, depression, anxiety, etc. The narrative  he presents as a new way of looking at these issues, and at life in general, is different from anything I’ve ever heard about. No matter who you are, you can probably benefit from reading this book!
title: Just as good as I had heard!

author: robinohara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: Did you ever think about the possibility of living an alternate life? This book explores the many regrets of a young woman who hates her life. She gets the chance to live out these lives through the Midnight Library — and learns, in similar ways to Jimmy Stewart’s character in “Its a Wonderful Life,” that seemingly small acts and decisions can change not only your life, but the lives of those around you.
title: Good and Fast Read

author: Carrie S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: I don't know how to feel about this book. It ia about a woman who wants to die but then gets to live in all these other lives of herself. I hate how she didn't know anything when she joined the other lives, I hate how the ones I was invested in didn't work ans how repetitive it became but then gripping at the end. It all wrapped up too neatly and too much philosophy ties.
title: So so 2.5

author: Holly Tracy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: Truly fantastic and I’d recommend to people who don’t consider fantasy their thing.  This is as much cerebral as it is fantasy, told in a simple fable-like way that makes it a quick read and easy to follow.  There’s a lot of sadness, but a lot of self-realization that can be found in the character’s loss and frustration about the meaning of happiness to the individual.
title: Fantastic

author: Christine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: Not sure what I expected as I had not read any of his other books. Bought it because the review made the book sound interesting. The sources of depression described by the protagonist reflect  the superficiality of our times.  Depression is a serious subject but this story seemed banal and bathetic. How this has risen to a number one best seller stupefies this reader.
title: A disappointingly shallow novel about depression and regrets

author: Raena
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2021
review_content: I have been looking for a book to engage me so much that I stop watching television. This was that book. I wanted to know everything about each book possibility Nora would try. The book has been seen as predictable but it does make you ask yourself the same questions which makes up for it. I am searching for another book along these lines of a multiuniverse setting.
title: Actives your thinking

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2021
review_content: Based on a clever premise, The Midnight Library is one of those head spinners that turns the concepts of time and reality on their heads. Are we really alone in this singular universe? But far more than a smart hook, this story tackles the everyday subject of despair and hopelessness and where it may lead ... and where it may come back from, given a second chance.
title: Far more than it seems

author: Guynz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
review_content: It's hard to live a book that has had excellent reviews. I found this book a bit light at times (and I felt like I was reading a YA book, rather than an adults book art times). The concept of the story also seemed similar to other 'what if' stories but it did go down a different route and went further. Still, after reading the book I felt impacted (in a positive way).
title: Good, but not fantastic.

author: LetMeSumUp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2021
review_content: Philosophy and Fiction, what a wonderful escape and brilliant lesson of a book that I'll keep with me. "Once you have read a book you care about, some part of it is always with you." - Louis L'Amour
title: Wow.

author: Idea Lady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2021
review_content: If you like to be depressed then by all means buy this book otherwise look for another book! Maybe if Amazon returned your money on the books you are sorry you bought..some critics and even authors would get the message!
title: Do Not Be Eager to Buy

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2021
review_content: When I first began reading this book, I almost put it down without finishing it. Something I very rarely do but this one was not for me! I decided to push on and am glad I did. This is a very good story for anybody, young or old, male of female, married or single.  Well written, nicely paced, good character development and an ending that you will remember and muse over for a while.
title: A lovely story

author: Todd Moffett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: I came to this book because of its appearance on bestseller lists, but man, reading this was like watching someone try on clothes for eight hours, only to see that person walk away with the same outfit. Also, let's get real. How many people in their lifetimes ever would have the chance to be an Olympic swimmer, a rock star, a lecturer at a premier university, a glaciologist. . . .
title: Overrated

author: JustGina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: Nora Seed is having what is possibly the worst day of her life when she decides that she doesn’t want to live anymore. But her attempt to end her life land her in the Midnight Library where a person from her past guides her to explore all of her regrets and her what-ifs. Can Nora find the perfect life?Matt Haig’s story is simplistically elaborate, with twists and turns, leading to an ending that will leave you pondering your own existence and its purpose.
title: Exquisite in its possibilities

author: Edward Y.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2020
review_content: I was drawn to this book because of the premise, that you can browse a sort of library and choose from infinite parallel lives to try out.  I really liked this book a lot, it was well written and the author did an amazing job of describing the main character's many lives in a clear and interesting way.  And I found the ending very satisfying, which is all I'll say here to avoid any spoilers.  So I highly recommend this book.
title: Well written, fascinating story

author: Grosme
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2021
review_content: I chose the rating because reading I found myself quickly just to get to the end. because NY family book club had chosen it and not because it was a pageturner. The concept of the parallel universes is a good one and some chapters were terrific but some were not. The uneveness was disappointing.  The main character who was on every page was not compelling.
title: Excellent concept not well executed

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
review_content: I've been on a dry spell for good books so when I read the summary for this I thought I would give it a try. The waiting list at my library was long so I decided to buy the book. I'm glad I did! This book has a bit of "A Christmas Carol" and a bit of "It's a Wonderful Life". But also a relevant and contemporary story as well. It's been a while since I have highly recommended a book to so many friends!
title: Loved it!

author: Travel Junky
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: The idea to be able to select multiple life options is intriguing-pick a path to follow and if you don't like it, throw it away and pick another.  A difficult concept to wrap your head around and even more difficult to write about.  I give the author credit for attempting to present such an experience but the book failed to provide the startling effects these various decisions can make on a person.  The main character seemed flustered but relatively unscathed.  The book needed more drama and life jolting events.
title: This book was a pleasant read.

author: Midwest Liberal, yeah Me
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
review_content: it sounded interesting in theory, but it's kind of a dismal, sad book.  Repeat rinse repeat.  The main character gets a chance to relive parts of her life she thinks she may have missed, then that isn't what she wants so she goes into another life and then another and another.  After awhile, I failed to care if she found her ideal life......such a good premise
title: Midnight Library.....

author: Dolly Womack
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021
review_content: Reading this book was like my mind going on 100 vacations. I could read Nora’s stories and picture my own. Then conjure my own results. It was a rollercoaster and I didn’t want to get off. I’m glad it ended the way it did, although I would have really loved an epilogue. To go into such detail about the other lives and not this one left me unsatisfied. But I guess that’s the point of life in a way, just not knowing.
title: Fascinating mind vacation

author: JeanMarie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2021
review_content: Matt Haig has been a favorite of mine on Instagram for a long while. His insights to life, mental health and human priorities are so wonderful and so needed especially in the last couple of years. This book is a culmination of all the good parts of Matt's talents and it will long be remembered as a creative, kind and healing journey for the weary soul.
title: This book can change your life or at least your perspective on your own life!

author: Julie C. Myers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: CW/TW: Suicide & DepressionMake sure you are prepared to read about someone who no longer wants to live. While the MC does go through a major mental transformation, just be aware that the first part of the story can be triggering. The book can be overly wordy at times due to the idealistic philosophy being hammered home, but it is not too detrimental to the overall story. The effect is still hopeful and as the novel wraps up, you are left with closure and optimism. Would recommend 7.5/10.
title: Sweet Story

author: Jeri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2021
review_content: If you are on the cusps of the next thing in your life or wanting to give up, this book is for you. This book feels like a self help book for those who lack in going on, but that is just under valuing this book’s content.This is one of the best books I have read in a while and it has tastefully managed depression, self harm and suicide without being pandering.
title: If you are struggling

author: Hannah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: This book is a cross between fantasy, sci-fi, and philosophy, and it seriously made me think!!! There is so much potential for what each of our lives could look like and The Midnight Library prompts you to unravel how all of your decisions have led you to where you are right this very second. The idea of being able to jump between billions of possible alternate lives was so fascinating, especially since Haig added a little bit of science/quantum physics to make it feel less fantastical. The most interesting lives to me were the ones where a very small decision completely changed her trajectory. I really enjoyed seeing Nora’s attitude towards her “root life” change throughout the book, but I’m only giving it 4 stars because the ending felt a little rushed and predictable. It’s a very fast read and I would recom
title: Book that makes you think

author: Pang Yang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2021
review_content: I first read this borrowed from my local library and needed it in my own library. Very heartfelt and open-minded. It hits different for each individual that reads it and connects different too. I bought this to reread when I feel I need it to help me get through the tough times or when I think it is time to go in a different direction in my choices.
title: Perfect book for 2020?

author: Lisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: Very glad I read this! A thoughtful, mindfultake on current concerns most of us humans face, being alive and keeping on keeping on.
title: A bit like 'Veronica decides to Die' , and not all.

author: Kristia P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed The Midnights Library. The idea was something I've never heard of before. It was a quick read, 5 hours or so which was nice. There were time it felt like the story drug on, which is why I'm giving it 4.5 stars. And indefinitely wanted to shake Nora by the shoulders a few times. But overall a great read and I highly recommend.
title: Lovely quick read

author: LBella
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: Loved. This. Book.It may be a little dark for some as it deals with suicide but it really less about that and  more about the twists and turns our lives take. This was the first book I’ve read by this author and I loved every word. If you ever have had a regret or have struggled with the “what if-s” in life this book is a powerful read.
title: Somethings for everyone in here

author: dswilson85
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: Someone has probably written this story before but I've never delved into the concept of parallel lives as I did with this book.  The ending is predictable but the journey to get there makes this a worthy read.  Gets a little bogged down and philosophical in the middle but then heads in an unexpected direction before its ultimate conclusion.  This book was Goodreads' "fiction read of the year".  I can see why.  The writing is solid, the "lives" within the overall plot are interesting, and I think most readers will find personal connections with the mindset and predicaments of the main character.
title: Quite the philosophical journey!

author: Art Spain
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
review_content: When I started this book I didn’t like it. The character of Nora irritated me, but I started wondering if I was really getting irritated with me. The more I read, the more I found things about myself. I’m not one of the people who necessarily enjoyed reading this book, but I’m one of the ones who needed it. I’m very glad I read it.
title: I didn’t necessarily enjoy this book, but I needed it.

author: Megan Sheehan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021
review_content: I bought this book because I thought the premise was really interesting, and I was looking forward to seeing how it was tackled. I thought the way that Matt Haig talked about mental health issues and depression was really well done and is important to talk about. It was really interesting watching Nora go through lives and try to find out what will make her truly happy, because it's something many of us do all the time. Plenty of us are still just trying to figure out how to be happy in life. Overall, I think this is the type of book that you can keep going back to and getting new meanings and messages from. I definitely recommend it!
title: A novel you can keep getting things from

author: AFC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2020
review_content: What a great story! A woman’s opportunity to “try on” her many potential lives in order to figure out if any of them are worth living. As someone living with depression it resonated so strongly with me. I highly recommend it for being an excellent and thought provoking read.
title: An Excellent Read!

author: KMB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: I really don’t understand why this book is so highly recommended. I found it super depressing. I really didn’t like it.I honestly think if this novel wouldn’t have come out during a global pandemic, where everyone had all the time in the world to contemplate their life choices, this novel wouldn’t be so popular.
title: Depressing

author: Kenh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2021
review_content: OK, I have not read a book this good in years.  The premise of having a library is weird.  I get it.  But boy does the author pull it off.  It is so darn thought provoking without knowing that you are really being challenged.  The pages just keep turning and you realize how fragile and wonderful life is.  A true must read!
title: Wow - what a trip.  A must read

author: Niru Canciello
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: So thought provoking to think how our lives would be different if we made different choices.  Midnight Library is a library composed of books that shows what one women's life story would be based on all the different choices she could have made.  The books also show how her decisions effected those around her.  Perfect Beach read and can't recommend enough!!
title: Easy Enjoyable read

author: Linda Roggli
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: What a lovely reminder that our choices create the reality of our lives. That the options we didn’t choose aren’t really regrets but opportunities to appreciate and reframe our current circumstance. A little bit “A Christmas Carol” and a little bit “It’s a Wonderful Life” the ending is predictable but precious. Well done!
title: Unusual and wonderful

author: Marcus Hyde
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2021
review_content: This book was recommended to me by a dear friend and colleague, who found a similarity in a book I had recently published. The quantum wave and infinite possibilities reflected in this story open doors of imagination and depth which are not only delightful to pursue as a reader, but are also inspiring to grasp as a fellow human being.
title: Potential

author: The Black Mzungu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review_content: I read "The Midnight Library" as part of a book club. It is not particularly my genre. It might be inspiration for many who struggle with depression and "what ifs". For those that have let their regrets in life consume themselves, it can give hope. For everyone else, the short chapters move fast offering  some suspense.
title: Hope and Suspense

author: Lori
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
review_content: I dont know how he does it. Matt Haig always writes the most beautiful portraits of what it means to be alive. He understands and explains the implicit beauty of the human experience.I am left feeling more hope than I did when I started reading. This is such a lovely, perfectly told story of joy and humanity. Thank you.
title: A masterpiece.

author: iMom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2021
review_content: Went into the book completely unaware of what it was about. It started out somewhat dark. Picks up quickly. Drags inJust a very few places. Truly brought perspective to my own thinkings (whether they stuck or not is a different story.) Finished in 3 days and am looking for the next read by this author. Loved it.
title: Uncomfortable and comforting all at once.

author: TRose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: This is a fantasy depicting one view of the brain dream complex one might experience on the edge of death. I am impressed by the author’s imagination and though I am not generally drawn to books that require a suspension of reality, if the reader allows the suspension the story offers a worthwhile experience. I recommend it.
title: A reason to live.

author: lc's mommy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: Love the concept in the book. Very well written, no annoying typos, and the idea is just so cool to think about because it’s so true - every tiny decision we make has an impact that reaches so far we can’t even imagine it.  And what we think might have changed our life for the better, may not have at all!  Recommend.
title: Very thought provoking

author: kristie ensley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: What are people raving about?! Apathy, boredom, complacency!No thank you.
title: I couldn't get through it!

author: Matt Rogge
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: A friend recommended this book to me and I have to say that I was not at all disappointed. I loved this read so much that I got through it in just a day and wish I could have savored it more but just could not put it down! This was a new author to me but I’m definitely interested in seeing if any of his other books are worth checking out.
title: A Must Read!

author: Tom Knorr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed this read. It came at a perfect time. My friend just ended his life when I was about 75% finished with this book. I needed this book right now. I needed the energy of the healing this book offered me. Great writing. Great read and really with covid depression setting in I just needed this book.
title: Pretty good, but no "It's a Wonderful life".

author: Richard M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: This book made me feel. I felt the power of possibilities that remain in my life. I felt the futility of thinking about what might have been. I felt the happiness of all the things in my life, good and bad, that make up the mosaic that is me. This novel truly is chicken soup for the soul. I highly recommend it!
title: Inspiring

author: esamily
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
review_content: Throughout the journey of the character in the book, you can just follow along with her. It's easy to put yourself in her shoes because no matter how old you are, she has a situation that could be experienced by anybody at any age. It makes the book quite unique because at first, I was just looking at books to help me not be bored or inefficient all the time. Thanks to that, I stumbled on one of the best books I've ever read. This book really made me question why I do things, and why those things are important to me!
title: The Best Book I've Ever Read

author: Ginger Russell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2020
review_content: The premise of this is interesting.  When I read the description, I had an idea in mind of what it would be like, and it wasn't what I thought.  Reading it gave me a very odd sense of time.  The plot is in no way predictable until possibly the very end.  Readers who like time slip books will probably like it.
title: Different

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
review_content: This story gives me something to think about.  Since my children grew up and left home  I sometimes wonder if I have much value.  The jobs I have had didn't seem of much importance and didn't pay much so I didn't get much credit for my work.  It is good mental exercise to put myself in this story and realize it is ok for me to relax a bit and enjoy my old age.
title: Interesting concept.

author: Ashley J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2021
review_content: By chance, I purchased this book yesterday. I didn’t know the premise, just that it had been popular so far. I was feeling suicidal and filled with despair. 23% in and I was in tears, laying next to my cat, and for the first time in my life saying aloud the good qualities I have and BELIEVING them. This book has changed my perspective on life, regrets, and the little things that I take for granted. It didn’t cure my depression, but gave me another view of it.So thank you Mark Haig for writing this. For managing to put into words the solitude and desolation that depression brings and for managing to build a world that wasn’t cliche but makes you question your own perspective.“Just be kind.”
title: Best book I have ever read

author: Pam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
review_content: Don't judge a book by its cover, or its title, but I usually ignore that.  This book has been calling me since I saw it on the bestsellers list.I tried out the sample, bought it and read it all this afternoon and evening.  It's a great idea for finding purpose in life and overcoming regrets.  Give it a try.
title: Lured by the title, again

author: McKenz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2020
review_content: What a great book! It came along at a good time for me since lately I see myself getting up there in years, and I have been thinking about many regrets. This book set me on a new way of thinking about things, and in this time of Covid-19 and political hatred, I found the book to be soothing and inspiring.
title: Thought Provoking and Inspiring

author: Mary Dickey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2021
review_content: I had no idea that this book would speak so much to me give me insight, clarity and potential for my own life.  It is filled with truths about oneself if you are open to listening.  A great read which provoked a great yearning to live more fully, appreciate life, friends and most of all myself.  Time to appreciate life.
title: A philosophical look at life

author: N. Dahiya
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2021
review_content: I enjoyed reading this immensely. Each new book of Nora’s life helped me understand how life is full of possibilities. We just need to open our eyes.The concept of helping out a down and out depressed person (Nora) who commits suicide but is technically not dead and then mke her want to live - loved it
title: A positive attitude book

author: Lisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021
review_content: I very nearly put this aside, because I wasn’t sure I wanted to follow what happened to the main character.  Then there was a twist, and it grabbed me and was compelling reading.  Interesting concepts worth mulling over outside the story.  Definitely worth the time.  The four stars is only because I think it really belongs at 4.5 stars—very good.
title: Unexpected

author: Momginerd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: I liked it until the end, where I feel like the author may have phoned it in a bit.  But it kept me interesting and anxious to see exactly how it ended.
title: Wry interesting read

author: Josh Roberts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2021
review_content: The character of this book Nora goes through extreme variations of life. Sees the different possibilities of many alternate universes if she would have made different decisions. The storyline is an interesting concept and the books deals with envy, suicide, depression. However, this book was not a rollercoaster of a novel it didn’t have the twists and turns or an enthralling ending. No it was more of a collected stories of this character with no real ending.
title: Story line seemed fascinating- Book lack entertainment

author: Rosa-maria Lazarovits
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review_content: This is our first book for our "Vista Book Club." It moved a great conversation forward. It is insightful and filled with great situations to discuss. It helps you go deep into unresolved issues with relationships and life-long philosophy questions. I truly enjoyed it.
title: quick and easy read

author: Walking Lady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
review_content: This story certainly seems like Science Fiction!  As a frequent reader I realize that the  stories we read have the power to allow us to experience different characters and places and time, though  we are still in our here and now.  This stepping into a story line and becoming a physical element and affecting those around us somehow didn't make it seem enjoyable to read.  I have loved fairy tales and fantasy and science fiction, so imagination has been my companion since childhood. (ie: Alice in Wonderland).  For whatever reason, this story just didn't touch me.
title: Curious tale!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021
review_content: To be honest I was a little unsure when I started this book. But the more I read, the more I was drawn in. My heart aches with the main character as she struggled to find her worth. But then as each story unfolded, so many nuggets of wisdom that we all need in life were discovered. These discoveries led to desires and growth... it didn’t end how I expected it to end, but I loved it anyway.
title: Great book with so many perspectives!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
review_content: I didn’t know it but I needed to read this book. I won’t write much about it, but suffice it to say that I completely identified with Nora, and felt the same transformation as I followed along on her journey.  I was moved to tears by this book, and that almost never happens.  I will be reading everything by this author!
title: Thanks, Matt Haig

author: Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review_content: This book explores the idea that our lives could look different in infinite  ways depending on the choices we make. While this is interesting and thought provoking, the book itself is not particularly compelling. It is a quick read and rather enjoyable, but feels predictable and at times, trite.
title: Interesting premise

author: Joanna Wiley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: Boring. Poorly written.  Perhaps this is for someone younger than 82. I’ve lived my regrets and always found a new path. Lucky old me.!
title: Boring. Overpriced and poorly written.

author: WECoyote
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: To one degree or another, I like all of Haig's writing. The ideas behind his fiction are imaginative and he keeps the story interesting. In a time where so much of what is written seems to focus on politics, coming of age, etc., it's nice to read a story that makes you forget the outside world for a while.
title: Not The Afterlife You Expect

author: Nancy Jackson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2021
review_content: A friend recommended this book. As a person who is intrigued by the string theory of quantum physics, I was thrilled to find this fictional story of how it supposedly works. Nora Seed and all her parallel lives will be remembered by this reader as an example of the value of there here and now. This story is a great way to conjure all the lives you might have led, to appreciate those in your present life who effect your journey in meaningful ways, and to realize how important it is to make this life matter, even in the smallest of ways. Great read, hard to put down and you're sorry when it ends.
title: Thought provoking

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2021
review_content: I quite enjoyed this read. I’m not sure how I really feel about parallel universes, but Matt did a very good job of making me more of a believer. Having myself been a victim of a suicide attempt, I completely agree that perspective is the key. How I was looking at things when I tried  to kill myself versus how I feel about life today are just completely different.
title: The Multiverse Lives

author: Damon Fecht
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2021
review_content: This novel has an interesting line of thought, but the characters aren’t well developed and the writing is somewhat flat. I find it hard to understand why this novel is a best seller.
title: Meh

author: alesia stanton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2021
review_content: I had a hard time getting used to the short choppy sentences at first, but once I got used to that I couldn't put it down! I felt like I was almost more invested in Nora's future than she was at times. I like the take on getting rid of your regrets. I would say that the best part for me was her learning to find the happiness in her original life and that we could all learn to be a little happier at times.
title: Choppy, but wonderful premise!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2021
review_content: I read a great deal but there are few books that I have difficulty putting down. This one is an exception , and contains thoughts that surely apply to all of us in some way.I shall buy a hard copy for my bookshelf and will probably reach for it many times.Thank you Matt Haig
title: Outstanding reading

author: Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: Wow!  Read over just two days. Couldn’t stop. It’s a genuine page turner. What a fine author, so totaling engaging, gentle but thorough. I can’t say enough. Characters and situations captivated me from the start. Just finished, and I’m reeling with delight!!Read it! Everyone!!  You will enrich your life!!!
title: Compelling

author: Mackie Faye Hill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
review_content: I am not usually one for easy reads like this, but this book just sucked me in. I fell in love with Molly...all of the Molly’s and couldn’t put the book down. The message is definitely a little preachy and sappy, but it is also very true. Don’t try to judge this book by depth...judge by creativity, warmth and enjoyability. It is a hit in my opinion!!
title: Good Clean Unadulterated Warm Fuzzies

author: Alyson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed The Midnight Library - it was charming, though-provoking, and it made me chew on my regrets a little; how many of them are truly regrets and how many are just decisions I may not have made with a little more information?  The novel was absolutely a pleasure to read and I've recommended it to a few of my friends.
title: A Palatable Way to Face Mortality

author: Jenny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: The title and cover....yes I know I shouldn't ever...led me to believe this was going to be a really good book. Also BAM and Amazon sort of led me to believe the same. It's very simplistic without much feeling. It would  be a pretty good book for a teen but past that it lacks maturity.
title: They really hyped this book

author: James Schrecengost
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review_content: Great book! 6 out of 5 stars. This author knows what happens in depressed minds and helps find a way out of depression.Hardest part to read is the Book of Regrets part. Keep reading past that. (It IS important to read that part!)I'd be very surprised if this book doesn't win many awards.
title: Best book for anyone who has ever thought about suicide. It's obvious this author knows.

author: Kreeesteeen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: To say I loved this book is an understatement. I was surprised by and totally enlightened by it. It’s smartly written with enough comedy to take the edge of the serious content. I had started like 6 books that I couldn’t get into and this was the one that finally put an end to my mediocre misery! Really pleased. I listened to the audiobook as well and the narrator was very nice. I will look at her other narrations as well. Thank you!
title: Wow

author: Fishing For Stuff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: Matt Haig is brilliant, and this book just wowed me.  Each chapter, each door/book felt like a short story, and because my attention span has been off, it made for the perfect read. Of course, Mr. Haig has the depth and emotion that kept me turning pages. Beautiful, important book.
title: To be savored...

author: Miss Patrish
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: Great book, very creative, very well-written!  I didn't want it to end.  I loved Nora, the main character and her evolution in her journey.
title: I loved everything about this book.....

author: avidreader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: Wasn't sure what to expect because I am not usually a fan of sci-fi or time travel but this book can be read in a much more spiritual way. Really liked the main character, Nora, and understood her life's regrets. I liked the way the author took us on many "what could have been" journeys and the ending wasn't quite what I expected. It was very enjoyable and pulled on your heart strings.
title: A wonderful message told in a unique way

author: Debra D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review_content: What a book! A “Midnight Library” between life and death where you can see different outcomes of your life based on your choices. It really makes you think about your choices in life- good and bad. And the endless possibilities. This book will be in my mind for a long time to come!
title: Life Changing!

author: Carol E. Burr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: A fascinating piece of magical realism with a suicidal beginning and an almost too upbeat ending. I loved the library of lives each of us can choose from and Haig's handling of placing his protagonist Nora in life paths she did not choose and showing they may not have produced any more fulfillment than her "root" life.
title: Regret is a waste of our precious lives.

author: Sharon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2021
review_content: What if you could live and see all of the different lives you might have lived if you had chosen a myriad of other paths? This is a book about Nora who does just that. Full of beautiful writing, lovely quotes and both funny and sad experiences, it is a meaningful novel that reinforces living. And living our best lives.
title: A Different View

author: Debora L. Schum
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: There are some clever twists in this book but in the end it is a take on everyone's favorite Xmas movie. It is a feel good book and contains some very good messages. As I was reading I thought of the Sheryl Crow lyric "it's not having what you want but wanting what you have".
title: Its a wonderful life

author: Sara S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2020
review_content: I have read over 600 books on my kindle in the last 10 years.  Most were self published, this book was printed by a publishing house. The premise of the book grabbed me and the writing and editing were worth the money spent. If I could give this book 10 stars I would.  I couldn't put it down and finished it in the wee hours of the morning.  Bravo!!
title: Womderful !!!

author: Kevin Carey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: A wonderful fable about pain, despair, regret, hope, family, friendship, and, ultimately, life in all its goods and bads. I soaked it up, savoring every chapter. So good. 10/10.
title: So good. 10/10

author: Marsha Noel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
review_content: Great read to get your mind redirected. Not a profound novel but a good start. Can’t wait to read the authors other books
title: Thought provoking

author: Jennifer J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2020
review_content: I love Matt Haig. The Humans is my favorite book in the world, and I love books. All of his books are fundamentally about the question of How are we humans going to find our lives worth living, in all their humanness. This book answers that question with a grace and loveliness even Matt Haig hasn’t had before. Engaging story, a main character to love, and profound wisdom woven through. In such a difficult year, this is the best gift ever. I am so grateful that the journey Haig has been on in his life offers such profound kindness, beauty, and hope to the rest of us.
title: Exactly the right book for now

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2021
review_content: As the book began I began to think it was going to be somewhat depressing. As things unfolded I slowly became more and more intrigued to the point I didn’t want to put it down. Interestingly the book was for me about a subject I have been reflecting on a great deal of late and off an on for many years. I hope many of you reading this review will take the same trip I did in reading this wonderful book. One of the best books I have read in a long time.
title: An amazing book

author: Michael W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2021
review_content: I did not care for this book for the vast majority of the story. The main character was too whiny for me. The premise is intriguing and I liked the idea of alternate lives but struggled to like the main character. In the end the book redeemed itself and I did like the ending.
title: Redemption

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2021
review_content: Have you ever read a book and wished you had thought of the story and written it yourself?  This book was interesting, funny, and thought provoking.  This story indirectly encourages the reader to consider whether they are living life according to their values and consider what is most important to us.
title: One of the best stories I've read in a while.

author: Mr. Orlando R. Barone
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: Just finished The Midnight Library. It’s a book about choices, any one of which can thrust you into a life vastly different from the one you are living. Infinite choices. But, as you’ll see, only one choice counts. Read this uplifting book and find out what that choice is.
title: Many Lives

author: MimzyCatz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2021
review_content: Book begins sad and dreary. it is an odd book and given the state of the world during this past year with turmoil and pandemic was not appealing. But, I plodded along and realized that the book helps us realize that life is about perspective and finding contentment in it.
title: Dreary to Cheery

author: Diane
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2021
review_content: This was a very good read. The author caught my attention right away. Interesting concept. We all have things in our life that we wish we could take back. Imagine if you did one thing different how that would affect your life and also the life of others!?! Really enjoyed
title: Regrets

author: truthsetsusfree
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2021
review_content: This was intriguing and very painful at times. I found myself exploring my own life and the choices I made, some good, some not so good. By the end, I found that there were far more good choices and I'm glad I was brave enough to go for them. Felt like I've been in therapy.
title: Makes you think.

author: A Blair
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: The storyline is great and truly captivates your interest.  It is thought-provoking because it raises some questions about your own life.  An enjoyable read.This was a selection for my book club.  This was certainly a great addition to the books we read bi-monthly.
title: Excellent Read

author: Connie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: One of the best books I have read this year.  It is sad, frustrating and yes joyful. You will not be disappointed. Matt Haig weaves a compelling story.  This is a page turner.
title: I am alive

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
review_content: Choices have consequences, and we chose new paths everyday creating a life. It is only at the far end we begin considering and collecting the regrets. Wouldn't it be wonderful to be able to stop and chose a new story when we realize we don't like where we have ended up?
title: Books about what could be

author: Mama J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: I imagine that we all dream about the "what ifs" in our lives. Nora Seed finds out when she ends up in an endless library. Her High School Librarian, a lady who was always kind to her is there to guide her as she steps in & out of several parallel existences.I couldn't put it down!
title: Engrossing and clever

author: Judyrh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2021
review_content: This book changed me.  I think often of it.  It is excellent reading and so intriguing and enlightening.  Halfway through The ending was a bit obvious but it was meant to be.  Great message and fun read.  Can’t wait for bookclub.  We might actually discuss the book. Ha!
title: Everyone should read this.  Fun read with a great message.

author: Maloney ✨
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2021
review_content: The author is likely a very good children's author as I could see children really liking this book.  But I found it fairly unremarkable and I'm not super hard to please.  I would recommend waiting and buying it at a thrift store in a year or so.... there will be plenty.
title: Yup, predictable and trite

author: Patrick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2021
review_content: Did not meet my expectations given the amount of favorable reviews.  I guessed the ending very quickly once Nora entered the library.  Way too many holes left in her other life experiences for me to care much.  The book had a good premise, just not executed very well.
title: Not that good

author: cpl1701
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2021
review_content: I really wasn’t sure if I would like this book when I heard that it dealt with suicide. I went back and forth about it for a while. But I’m so glad that I gave it a chance. I absolutely loved it. It started out hard but that was necessary to tell the story. It’s actually very uplifting and I couldn’t wait to see what happened next. I would definitely recommend.
title: You don’t have to understand life, you just have to live it.

author: PJGyrl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
review_content: Into the despair and desperation of Nora Seed's seemingly hopeless life, The Midnight Library offers a chance to see that "it's not what you look at that matters, but what you see." Wise, philosophical, and brimming with charm and imagination, this book is a keeper.
title: Matt Haig shines!

author: Alexis Ortiz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: I'm unable to articulate in the incredible Matt haig fashion how much this story means to my body, soul and spirit. Sharing this book with every person I know as the wild times call for these lessons to be spread to the world. I feel lighter, inspired, and grateful! Thank you Matt Haig for the light and love you've yet again shared with this particular dimension and the infinite others!
title: the metaphors and messages are DIVINE

author: DStraker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2021
review_content: If you keep an open mind to Life. This is a generous story all the lives you could live if you open your mind to the possibilities. I loved the multiple stories this book gave the reader. Read it. It will make you happy to be alive.
title: Time is on your side...

author: Dana S. Whitney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2021
review_content: Dissatisfied, but not sure why, Nora Seed has a series of parallel lives to live before she fully embraces life.
title: Fabulous antidote for depression or doldrums.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: This book made me think every step of the way about my own life. Nora is a.wonderful person that you feel for.  A deep, interesting way to look at how life can beat you up but every thing you go through is a step worth taking. Enjoy the ride.  Thank you, Matt Haig!
title: Fantastic!  You must read this.

author: NOLA person
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2021
review_content: I suppose in some other parallel universe, this may be considered great literature; but in my current one it's just meh.  There were some golden nuggets in this predictable tome; but more eloquently found from the original philosophers.
title: Meh

author: Alexis Romine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: This book was very nice. I had a great time delving into the many lives of Nora Seed. It made me feel good by the end and had a very conclusive feel. I like that even though the premise is so dark, it really works around to be a very wholesome and optimistic story.
title: Very sweet and endearing

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2021
review_content: A stunning and beautifully written book that examines our "what ifs ?" and helps to place them into the context of our current lives. We all have regrets about the choices we make.  Haig  brings those regrets into focus through this story and provides perspective into how those regrets affect our lives. His characters are so very human and real.  They could be us.
title: Stunning

author: Laura
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2021
review_content: I love the idea of parallel universes. It is so interesting, confusing, and exciting! Ha! Ha! All at the same time!! I’ve wondered many times, in some specific circumstances, “what if?” But then, I see my life and realize I am exactly where I should be so it was easy (aside from ever wanting to die!- so sad) to identify with the outcome. Mrs. Elm reminded me of my grandmother, one of the most important characters in my life! We all need some help some time. Thanks you for a good read!
title: Regrets...we all have them!

author: Barb G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: THE MINUTES YOU READ THE FIRST FEW PAGES, YOU KNOW EXACTLY WHAT WILL HAPPEN.  The story is so trite, so forced, the expanations so phony and dumb...and this is on the best seller list?  just awful...Harry Potter books are like Shakespeare compared to this fake
title: WHAT A PIECE OF OLD CHEESE THIS IS

author: Karen Hamilton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: Thought the concept was very interesting, and it made me think too, about life and regrets.  Occasionally I became bored, then was intrigued with where it was going.so, overall I enjoyed it, and ill remember it.  Would I recommend it?  Put it.with the others on the list.
title: Not quite sure.  Imagination required

author: Aunt Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: I have been hungering for a beautifully written book with depth and wisdom. This is the book I’ve been waiting for. There are so many passages I underscored, passages that resonated with my life as a psychotherapist and as a spiritual traveler. Thank you, Mr. Haig.
title: A Wonderful Read

author: Brad Temple
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2021
review_content: I generally enjoyed reading this, though I don't feel it will be super memorable for me, personally. It could've gone in more interesting directions, but it didn't end up where I had hoped after the time it spent developing the core story. I definitely don't regret reading it. It's quick to get through, so I suggest picking it up if it sounds interesting to you.
title: Good, but a little average.

author: asmanda2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
review_content: The midnight library brings to light the struggle so many with depression face each day: regret. His novel captures the truth of regret and how choice impacts our futures and those around us. Read in 24 hours
title: Couldn’t put it down. A modern day version of choose your own adventure.

author: N L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2020
review_content: It's refreshing to read, as I've placed myself in the mind's eye of the main character, I had felt heartwarming, and empathy for the protagonist.  It's nice to read this book because I felt empowered in ways, and a way to harness myself into a relaxed and contented state, especially given the current circumstances of life.
title: A Worthy Read!

author: Marcia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: Imagine each of us has a book or regrets and they can  be undone by choosing a different path...but make one change and multitudes of others follow...so do you keep what you have or try something new? Great fun imagining if the young Nora was me...I would have loved trying out new lives. Many inspirational moments...I'd buy it as a graduation gift for a high school student and then read it together and talk about it!  It's a keeper!
title: If you could undo one regret..what would your life be like now?

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review_content: While this starts a bit slow, it gains momentum at around the halfway point. An easy read, with characters to care about and root for. And an interesting take on the multiverse that allows acceptance by any reader. Saying more would spoil the fun of discovery.
title: READ THIS!

author: Bridget Pagano
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2021
review_content: I absolutely loved this novel. It was such a great read- I couldn’t put it down. Despite being fiction, it definitely inspired some fresh perspective in my life and a deeper sense of gratitude in my soul. Great book club piece, airport pickup, or beach read.
title: Must add to your library.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: A perspective on life and death somewhat different and somehow not, but especially in this tumultuous time it gives good food thought.  Perhaps you need to be open-minded first, but maybe not. However it may lack of clarity is confusing, perhaps you need to read this book.
title: I loved this book

author: runner27
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: This is one of those rare books that grab you and hold you. Yes, it is about a difficult subject, however, this author manages to bring some hope to his protagonist. His writing is nothing short of brilliant. No spoilers here- just read. You won't regret it.
title: Great read-highly recommend

author: Will Landon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021
review_content: An intriguing premise too often diluted with flat, unimaginative prose; weak characterization; and a dismayingly simplistic portrayal of mental illness. But while the story fell flat for me, it did explore some interesting ideas and leave me with a refreshing sense of hope.
title: Interesting premise, not-so-interesting execution

author: Gelsyn Ferrera
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2021
review_content: Reading through the "Review" section (which I do not recommend before buying any book), I came across a lot of criticism in regards to the main character and the plot of the story. In my opinion, Matt Haig goes beyond telling a story by bringing awareness to an issue that is affecting many, especially during the current global pandemic circumstances. There is a brief feeling of educating by the author amidst the story through narrative. Nevertheless, the message of the book should not be dismissed.
title: Easily Dismissed

author: Marv
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
review_content: Full of philosophical insights that aren't written in a stuffy manner.  The character's life changes and with that comes considerable insight for the readers to think about and probably adopt into their life.  Remarkable insights especially from my "fav" Thoreau.
title: Great zRead

author: Robert S. Tyler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
review_content: Each decision we make leads to a new branch in the tree of our life. Each decision also effects people other than ourselves. Have you ever wondered what it would be like to jump from branch to branch experiencing the each of these tiny twigs? Maybe it feels like the Midnight Library.
title: Parallel universes are an interesting concept

author: Caroline Mcvitty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
review_content: This story rang so true.  I am in my early 80’s and I swear the book confirms my primal belief about life:  wherever I am is where I am supposed to be.  It would be lovely to try on other lives.  But then who would be there to influence the people we have met in our root life?
title: Everyone’s Story if you have lived long enough

author: lysbeth spence
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: Beautiful book, beautifully written.  Moral of appreciating the gift of life which is always filled with possibilities.  Author gets it that life is self generated.  Change is a matter of making another choice.  Don't read it as fiction, read it as a possibility.
title: Gratitude

author: Kaer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2021
review_content: This book was interesting as Nora went from life to life but it was difficult to connect the dots until the very end. Haig took a long time to make his point. I kept wanting for the narrative to speed up and when it did, it was with short, brief statements about Nora’s lives.
title: Interesting but a little slow...

author: Gwen B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2021
review_content: Great book! Makes you appreciate the life you have and think about all the possibilities you chose not to take. What would your life be like if you had...  Also made you realize that the little things you do for others makes a huge difference in the world.
title: The Midnight Library

author: ERS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
review_content: Not all would like this book as it starts off on a down note, but the journey the main character takes is one that goes through so many minds - what if? What if you chose the other path at a key decision in life? Strong philosophy ties throughout. Loved it.
title: Well written, insightful
